description: PARIS  The migrant crisis in France has shifted from the Jungle of Calais to the streets of Paris, with hundreds camped out in tents in the citys northern neighborhoods and dozens more arriving each day.

title: Video Review: McLaren 570GT Is a Rare Blend of Speed and Comfort
description: LIKE many red-blooded American children, I spent high school study hall poring over the pages of car magazines. I ignored my English homework (surprise, Mrs. Oberg! Im that Tom Voelk); my interest was in art. Ferrari and Lamborghini sculpture, that is.

title: Justin Trudeau and the Sludge of Canadian Mining Companies
description: MONTREAL  Canada is back, says Justin Trudeau, the charismatic and bilingual prime minister of Canada, at international gatherings, seeking to showcase the imprint he wants to put on Canadian foreign policy in contrast to that of his predecessor, Stephen Harper. The prime minister has used very precise terms in his speeches: justice, environmental care, democracy and human rights. He even dared to invoke some of them during his official visit to China in September, although the Chinese did not applaud him for it.

title: How Economic Data Is Kept Politics-Free
description: Talk about an October surprise. The post on Twitter warning of a government conspiracy to swing the presidential election in the Democrats favor popped up just moments after the Labor Department reported the biggest monthly decline in the unemployment rate in nine years.

title: Guggenheim Helsinki Supporters Revise Plan
description: In an attempt to keep a Guggenheim Helsinki alive, supporters of the project on Thursday morning presented an updated proposal for the construction of the museum.

title: Mike Mitchell and Walt Dohrn Discuss a Scene From Trolls
description: The animated comedy Trolls brings the fuzzy-haired toy dolls to enthusiastic life on the big screen. In this scene, Anna Kendrick provides the voice of Poppy, a troll setting off on a dangerous journey, cheerfully indifferent to the hazards along the way.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Painters Headaches
description: The Challenge: A 63-year-old painter develops headaches that become increasingly devastating, associated with changes in the way he sees and interacts with the world. Can you explain why?

title: Octavia Spencer Cracks a Few Hollywood Equations
description: TORONTO  On a film set in Canton, Miss., two decades ago, Octavia Spencer got a big break, and a foreshadowing that others might be harder to catch. She was in her mid-20s, working as a production assistant on the Matthew McConaughey-Sandra Bullock thriller A Time to Kill. She asked the director Joel Schumacher if she could read for a small part: perhaps the woman who starts a riot?

title: South Koreas Metastasizing Crisis
description: South Koreas President Park Geun-hye is embroiled in a lurid corruption scandal that threatens to hamstring her remaining year in office. The scandal has plunged Ms. Parks approval ratings to record lows, sent thousands of angry demonstrators into the streets, and sparked demands that she resign.

title: 1916: French Push On North of Somme Despite Downpour
description: The persistence of the rain on the Somme front is seriously hindering infantry operations, but despite this the Allies continue to display a certain activity. During Wednesday night and yesterday [Nov. 2] the French troops never relaxed their efforts between Sailly-Saillisel and Lesboeufs, and as a result have considerably improved their position.

title: Nashville Celebrates Its Heroes and Welcomes Beyonc to C.M.A. Awards
description: Nashville extolled its heroes and loyal insiders at the 50th annual Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night, honoring Garth Brooks, Dolly Parton, Randy Travis and Merle Haggard. But it also made a point to demonstrate its pop-world openness with a rousing performance by Beyonc and the unexpected return of Taylor Swift, who has long since outgrown her country side.

title: Venezuelas Tone-Deaf President
description: It was a curious week for President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela to launch a jovial radio show.

title: Family Disputes and a Nasty Can of Beans: Hillary Clinton as Litigator
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  They called him Tiny, naturally, because he was anything but. A bouncer at a pawnshop here, the man significantly outweighed most of the stores customers and would-be robbers. Now, he stood accused of roughing up his girlfriend.

title: 36 Hours in Manhattan, Below 59th Street
description: The center of the world  filled with restaurants and glamorous nightclubs  lies between Central Park and the Battery.

title: The Importance of Facial Equality
description: I have never seen someone who looked like me on a mainstream television show. I have never seen someone who looked like me, playing anything but a villain in movies, or in an ad or on a billboard. I am invisible. That is, until I walk down the street. That is, until strangers stare just a little too long and rudely whisper, look at her eyes.

title: Why English Keeps On, Like, Totally Changing
description: THE WORD DETECTIVESearching for the Meaning of It All at the Oxford English DictionaryBy John Simpson364 pp. Basic Books. $27.99.

title: Lela Slimani Wins Prix Goncourt, Frances Top Literary Award
description: PARIS  Lela Slimani, a French-Moroccan novelist, was awarded Frances top literary accolade, the Prix Goncourt, on Thursday for her book Chanson Douce (Sweet Song), a thriller that opens with the killing of two young children by their caretaker.

title: Article 50: Reviewing the Road Map for Brexit
description: LONDON  Britain voted in June to leave the European Union. But the process truly began on March 29, when the government invoked a treaty provision  Article 50  that set out the basics of a withdrawal.

title: About Time
description: Test your knowledge of the science and philosophy of time.

title: What Locker-Room Talk Sounds Like in the Philippines
description: Machismo isnt quite what it used to be. Backlash and hashtags now hold politicians accountable for their so-called locker-room talk in much of the world. Yet the Philippines remains a glaring example of how men use language and law to try to emasculate opponents and maintain power.

title: Lead Plaintiff in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Had Advanced C.T.E.
description: BOSTON  The former running back Kevin Turner, one of the lead plaintiffs in the landmark N.F.L. settlement over concussions and brain trauma, had the most advanced form of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, researchers said Thursday.

title: Google Rebuts Antitrust Claims in Europe
description: To many Europeans, Google represents Silicon Valleys perceived stranglehold on the digital world. But on Thursday, the American search giant tried to portray itself as a stalwart of online competition as it responded to European antitrust charges that it had restricted consumers choices and hamstrung its competitors.

title: Mark Leckey Captures the Exuberance of Pre-Brexit Britain
description: No one Pauline Kael knew voted for Richard M. Nixon, and no one I know voted for Brexit. I lived in London for a little over three years, and that catastrophic British referendum of June 23, and the political meltdown, legal uncertainty and racist violence it has unleashed, have obliterated a place I thought I knew, and left the British art world unmoored.

title: Rodrigo Duterte Plays U.S. and China Off Each Other, in Echo of Cold War
description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines traveled to Beijing recently, promising to announce his countrys separation from the United States and alarming the White House and his own defense secretary.

title: For Beyonc, an Unexpected Performance in an Unexpected Look
description: Beyonc, an artist known for dominating R&B and pop charts, performed at the Country Music Awards in Nashville on Wednesday, causing a few of the genres fans to scratch their heads and all of her fans to go into the usual paroxysms of delight.

title: More Than 200 Migrants Drown Off Libya Trying to Reach Europe
description: More people are dying while attempting to cross the Mediterranean from Libya to Europe: at least 239 drowned in two separate shipwrecks, the United Nations reported on Thursday.

title: Growing Up Gay to a Glam Rock Soundtrack
description: In early 1976, I saw Freddie Mercury stage one of the greatest charades in rock history. He was appearing with his band Queen at the Beacon Theater at a pivotal time, just three months after the release of Bohemian Rhapsody but a season before the song entranced the pop mainstream.

title: Donald Trumps Income Isnt Always What He Says It Is, Records Suggest
description: On the financial disclosure forms that Donald J. Trump has pointed to as proof of his tremendous success, no venture looks more gold-plated than his golf resort in Doral, Fla., where he reported revenues of $50 million in 2014. That figure accounted for the biggest share of what he described as his income for the year.

title: Cubs Players React to Win
description: The Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year drought on Thursday when they won the World Series. The Cubs topped the Cleveland Indians, 8-7.

title: Ebola Evolved Into Deadlier Enemy During the African Epidemic
description: The Ebola epidemic that tore through West Africa in 2014 claimed 11,310 lives, far more than any previous outbreak. A combination of factors contributed to its savagery, among them a mobile population, crumbling public health systems, official neglect and hazardous burial practices.

title: The Best New Movies on Hulu
description: Election

title: Elite Runners Ryan and Sara Hall Add Parenting to Their Workouts
description: When the elite distance runners Sara and Ryan Hall adopted four sisters from Ethiopia in October 2015, it was the start of a year of seismic changes for them.

title: Lindsey Adelman on Sharing a Visual Language With Her Husband
description: In this series for T, the writer and author of Worn Stories, Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

title: Make Siri Hear You on a Mac Mini
description: Q. MacBooks and iMacs have built-in microphones, but how do you use Siri on a Mac Mini?

title: In Russia, a Western Taste for High-End Auto Sales
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The automotive history of the former Soviet Bloc resonates with cars like the funky Lada, the futuristic Tatra, the clunky but lovable Trabant and the luxurious Volga. Then there was the tanklike Zil  always in black  that shuttled Nikita S. Khrushchev and Alexei N. Kosygin through Red Square.

title: The History of Southern Africa, by Train
description: JUST A FEW HOURS INTO our train ride, we know the passengers in the cabins on either side of ours: On one side are two young Canadians on a monthslong, round-the-world backpacking trip. On the other are four middle-aged women on a trading expedition from their towns in Zambia to Dar es Salaam, where theyll buy supplies for their shops, including clothes and spare parts for cars. Theyre not waiting to get to Dar to get started: At every whistle-stop town along the way, vendors try to sell things through the window  often produce at prices far below those in the Tanzanian metropolis. So the women are stocking up on items they can sell for a profit when we arrive in a day or two: tomatoes, oranges, passion fruit, boiled peanuts and, just this morning, roasted caterpillars.

title: Parks and Jubilations
description: The top galas of the past week were hosted by Fashion Group International, the Central Park Conservancy, Performa and Lincoln Center.

title: Whose Life Should Your Car Save?
description: The widespread use of self-driving cars promises to bring substantial benefits to transportation efficiency, public safety and personal well-being. Car manufacturers are working to overcome the remaining technical challenges that stand in the way of this future. Our research, however, shows that there is also an important ethical dilemma that must be solved before people will be comfortable trusting their lives to these cars.

title: The New York Times Best Illustrated Childrens Books of 2016
description: Every year since 1952, the Book Review has convened an independent panel of judges to select the New York Times Best Illustrated Childrens Books. Judged purely on artistic merit, its the only annual award of its kind.

title: Parks and Jubilations
description: The Fashion Group International held its annual Night of Stars gala on Oct. 27 at Cipriani Wall Street, where luminaries like Tommy and Dee Hilfiger were honored. The Central Park Conservancy autumn gala took place Oct. 27 under a clear tent at the parks Naumburg Bandshell. Performa hosted its fall gala on Tuesday at the Altman Building and honored the curator, art critic and poet Okwui Enwezor. And Lincoln Center honored Laurie M. Tisch at its fall gala on Tuesday at the Jazz at Lincoln Center Frederick P. Rose Hall.

title: Rodrigo Dutertes Pledge to Stop Cursing Lands in the Gutter
description: HONG KONG  When President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines vowed last week to stop cursing, at Gods direct request, few people in the deeply Catholic country questioned his faith or the logistics of the apparently divine intervention.

title: A Souvenir for Anthony Rizzo, a Gift for All Cubs Everywhere
description: CLEVELAND  Anthony Rizzo was 3 years old when his father, John, first knew he might be a baseball player.

title: Donations to Religious Institutions Fall as Values Change
description: It used to be that many people gave to their particular house of worship to get a prominent pew or extra blessings. Or because their grandparents and parents had always attended that church or synagogue or mosque.

title: If I Were President . . . of My Club, My Class, My College, My Country
description: We asked students what they would do if they were in charge, what their concerns and hopes for the future would be. Empathy and forgiveness  a plea for more  and climate change were recurring themes, as well as issues political and personal. Here are condensed selections. Add your own ideas in the comments section at the bottom of this page (student submissions will be highlighted). Photos and drawings that interpret the question can be submitted via email, to edlife@nytimes.com.

title: Daily Report: A New Helper in the Virtual Assistant Race
description: Gadget geeks will get their chance to size up a new toy at the end of this week when Google brings out Home, its voice-activated smart speaker powered by a virtual assistant.

title: Killing of Saudi Student Shakes Wisconsin College Town
description: For nearly a week, the police in Menomonie, Wis., have been at a loss to identify a suspect or a motive in the fatal beating of a Saudi Arabian college student outside a pizza restaurant. Now, the city is trying to change that by raising money for a reward. The tally so far? $20,000.

title: Art Museums Are Looking for That Next Big Gift
description: Public museums, too tight on money these days to compete for major artworks in the marketplace, long for the collectors gift of world-class art that can broaden their offerings and attract new audiences.

title: Violets Bake Shoppe
description: The golden banh mi ratio lives at this storefront in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: For Banh Mi, Violets Bake Shoppe Has the Math Down
description: Some argue that banh mi, the Vietnamese sandwich, lives and dies by its bread, a cloud in crisp armor, preferably made with a pinch of rice flour for extra spring and crackle.

title: Cubs, Nerds and True Baseball
description: Heres a question about last nights exhilarating, stomach-churning, 10-inning seventh game of the World Series between the Cubs and Indians: Was it true baseball?

title: It Was 74-17 at Halftime. Then the Score Got Out of Hand.
description: If you gambled on womens college basketball on Wednesday night, and you had Bluefield State plus 128, you lost.

title: The Philharmonic to Stream Young Peoples Concerts
description: When the New York Philharmonic televised its Young Peoples Concerts from 1958 through 1972, it introduced new generations to classical music. Now the orchestra is updating the program: It said Thursday that it was putting videos of Young Peoples Concerts, and additional educational materials and interactive games, online for schools and families to stream for free.

title: A Joyful World Series for a Weary Country
description: It was 10 innings that to both sides felt like 10 months or 10 generations, this midnight final contest between benighted Midwestern teams, each so deserving and so long denied.

title: A Shortage of Oncologists
description: In the crucible of cancer treatment, the bonding of patients with physicians often makes the unendurable endurable. The difficulty of finding and then keeping the right oncologist can therefore be fraught. Yet this problem, not uncommon today, is on track to grow worse.

title: A Healthy Dressing Recipe From L.A.s Newest Feel-Good Cafe
description: Dietary dogma is so strong in Los Angeles that even Dodgers Stadium offers vegan and gluten-free options for fervent-but-sensitive gamegoers. And down the road at Honey Hi in Echo Park, Eastsiders are catching a new wave of nutrition. Its not strictly vegetarian, vegan, paleo, raw, plant-based, ayurvedic or superfoodist. The restaurants guiding principle is what they call a radical inclusivity. But according to its co-owner Kacie Carter, a chef and nutritionist, Honey Hi isnt a movement, its simply a little cafe with delicious food that makes you feel good.

title: On the Trail: Wednesday November 2
description: Donald Trump held rallies in Florida and Hillary Clinton held a rally in Arizona, visited Las Vegas and made a surprise stop in Florida.

title: Your Questions About the U.S. Election, Answered
description: Declan Walsh, who has been reporting on the U.S. presidential campaign as a foreign correspondent, is answering questions from readers as the election nears. Below, he responds to  readers interested in the tenor of the campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump; the practice of voters who split their ballot; and what states will ultimately decide the election.

title: What Lady Gagas Bad Romance and Other Earworm Songs Have in Common
description: You should stop reading this now. No really, just dont. Youre still reading. O.K., you asked for it:

title: 10 Books We Recommend This Week
description: Halloween may be over, but the world still feels very dark. This week, our critics and editors at the Book Review recommend 10 grim books for grim times.

title: Why Washington Needs Wall Street
description: The latest round of drumbeating has begun to prevent anyone with a Wall Street background from filling the top economic positions in the next administration. Not only is that not right, it hurts the American people by preventing those who have the best understanding of how financial markets work from taking a much-needed role in policing and fixing them. It is a form of discrimination. The time has come for it to stop.

title: A Photographers Homage to an Architects Modernist City
description: Martien Mulders The City Beautiful is an exploration of the quiet weight of the relationship between light and space in Le Corbusier-designed Chandigarh, India.

title: Russian Sports Agent and U.S. Marathon Officials Under Federal Investigation
description: The Russian sports doping scandal has led United States law enforcement officials to an unlikely spot: Manhattans Upper West Side.

title: 19 Countries, 43 States, 327 Cities: Mapping The Timess Election Coverage
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

title: Credit Suisses Cost-Cutting Is Hindered by Rising Risks
description: The chief executive of Credit Suisse, Tidjane Thiam, recently described Europes banks as uninvestable. His banks third-quarter results make Credit Suisse look just as bad.

title: Rebuilding After Hurricane Sandy
description: To the Editor:

title: What Really Happened to Raoul Wallenberg?
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Trumps Tax Maneuvers
description: To the Editor:

title: Melania Trump, Solo in Pennsylvania, Tries to Smooth Husbands Rough Edges
description: BERWYN, Pa.  Melania Trump made a rare appearance on the campaign trail in the battleground state of Pennsylvania on Thursday, seeking to soften her husbands coarse image by proclaiming to voters that Donald J. Trump respects all Americans and promising that as president he would promote values of compassion and charity across the country.

title: From Sliced Bread to Gas Prices, Obama Takes Stump Speech Off Script
description: MIAMI  President Obama is savoring what is likely to be the last intensive political campaign of his life, and his speeches have been running so long that 30 minutes were tacked onto his official schedule Thursday to compensate.

title: Iraqis Fear Bloodshed Will Continue After Mosul if Sectarian Tensions Arent Addressed
description: ERBIL, Iraq  As Iraq comes closer to ejecting the Islamic State from its last major stronghold in the country, the question is no longer whether it can succeed.

title: The 90s Designer Making a Big Comeback  All Over the Runways
description: Even during his heyday of the early- to mid-90s, the French designer Jean Colonna was an insider name  but today, his style is all over the runways. In 1993, The Times dubbed him the popularist of Drugstore Cowboy dressing: a pithy acknowledgment of his aesthetic, which relied heavily on synthetic fabrics, especially pleather, machine-made lace and machine-sewn sequins, animal prints and brash color combinations of black with violet, hot pink or lipstick red. It looked trashy  it did then, and it does now.

title: When It Comes to Success, Age Really Is Just a Number
description: The question hangs over the career of every ambitious soul: Is there still time to make a mark?

title: Veterans and the Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt Floats Currency, Appeasing I.M.F. at Risk of Enraging Poor
description: CAIRO  Egypts central bank on Thursday said it would soon allow the countrys currency to trade freely, part of a broader effort to save a free-falling economy and combat an increasingly prevalent black market for American dollars.

title: Saying No to Breast Reconstruction
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Test Kitchen Lawsuit
description: Read the complaint filed in Suffolk County Superior Court in Massachusetts.

title: Food Fight Heats Up as Americas Test Kitchen Sues a Founder
description: Christopher Kimball was dressed in a Victorian costume and heading out the door to trick-or-treat with young relatives Monday evening when he got word that one of the food medias messiest divorces was about to get a lot messier.

title: Kid-Wrangling 101
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Andy Newman, a metro reporter, shares whats involved in helping a group of middle-school-age city kids produce the stories of their lives.

title: My First Film Fest: A Mix of Dark Themes and Sunny Attitude
description: You wouldnt expect someone who had just created a movie festival for children  especially one that began on Thursday with a sneak preview of DreamWorks Animations cheerful-looking Trolls  to heave a sigh and exclaim, Oh, my God, so many dark films! Yet that was how Florence Almozini, associate director of programming for the Film Society of Lincoln Center, recently characterized her latest venture.

title: Man Is Arrested in Killing of Brooklyn Pizzeria Owner
description: In the days after the killing of an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, speculation grew: Could it have been the settling of a score, perhaps related to a long-simmering feud over a tomato sauce recipe?

title: Review: Fold. Spindle. Mutate. Oh, Its Gibney Dance.
description: Behind the scenes, Gina Gibney is a force in the New York dance world, presiding over two dance centers along lower Broadway. Shes long been a choreographer, too, and this year she celebrates the 25th anniversary of Gibney Dance. With that comes Folding In, her first work since 2013.

title: Mosul, Brexit, Donald Trump: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Diary of a New York City Marathon, Now With a Finishing Kick
description: In 2012, I set out to examine the atmosphere, history and landmarks along the New York City Marathon route, one mile per day, in the 26 days leading up to the race.

title: Iggy Pops Life Drawing Class
description: The artist Jeremy Deller organized a live drawing class in which students from art schools around the city drew the music icon.

title: Iggy Pop: Musician, Icon  and Now, Live Nude Model
description: Ever since James Newell Osterberg Jr. emerged from a Detroit trailer park and reinvented himself as the snarling, bleached-blond, Dionysian rock god Iggy Pop, he has been one of the most iconic figures in music. With his sinewy frame and defiant stare, Iggys image has been immortalized by the likes of photographer Mick Rock (on the cover of his band The Stooges third album, Raw Power) as well as the artists Peter Hujar and Gerard Malanga. I knew him from the imagery before the music, actually, recalls the Turner Prize-winning British artist Jeremy Deller. Even in photos you can tell he has a presence and is clearly quite a character. For Deller, it was Iggys baring of his torso and soul onstage that struck him: Hes not stopped performing, Deller says. From the age of 20 to 69, its been a continuous piece of performance art and documentation of his body. Its interesting to me for a man to parade his body so much, and parade it as it changes.

title: The Voter Fraud Lie We Cant Shake
description: Early voting is underway, and according to Donald J. Trump, so is voter fraud. Almost daily, he proclaims that large-scale voter fraud is happening and that the election is rigged. Politicians across the spectrum have criticized this nonsense as divorced from reality, deleterious to our democracy and unprecedented in our elections.

title: Connections to a Cause: The Millennial Way of Charity
description: WASHINGTON  It was an otherwise routine bus ride through the Costa Rican countryside several years ago that changed the way Chase Adam thought about what makes people give.

title: Luke Cage Made Him a Fashion Hero
description: Mike Colter plays the coolest superhero going these days, on the binge-worthy Netflix show Luke Cage. Mr. Colter, who grew up in St. Matthews, S.C., let us in on his favorite clothing, explained how his role as a Marvel character has changed his wardrobe, and revealed why he prefers boots with zippers.

title: In a Bar in Chicago, the Real M.V.P.s of the Series Got It Done
description: CHICAGO  Fifth inning, Game 7 of the World Series, and the Chicago Cubs were comfortably ahead by four runs. What more auspicious moment could there be for an out-of-town visitor to sneak into a friendly bar full of happy fans who were watching their team coast to victory?

title: The Virtual Splendor of Pariss Glass House
description: Discovering the existence of the Maison de Verre in Paris can be a major aesthetic epiphany. When you see a photograph of this translucent structure in glass, steel and expanses of glass brick  completed in 1932  the impression is of startling modernity, something very much of its time yet strikingly ahead of it, too, like Picassos Les Demoiselles dAvignon or Duchamps The Large Glass.

title: Going Head to Head With Pierre Chareau
description: The spare simplicity of the introductory galleries of the Jewish Museums new exhibition on the interior designer Pierre Chareau  even the inventive moving silhouettes on scrims there  do not prepare you for the fully immersive virtual reality experiences in the shows second-to-last gallery.

title: Green-Wood Cemetery, Where Presidential Aspirants Enjoy an Afterlife
description: LET us now consider a particular presidential candidate who made a fortune in business and real estate, who reveled in being famous, who had never held elective office before and who urged his supporters to cancel their subscriptions to a newspaper that had called him an idiot.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the post-election prognosis, and other news. Susan Lehman is host.

title: Unlocking the Secrets of Boxwood Miniatures
description: Dutch woodcarvers once sculpted slivers of boxwood into biblical scenes smaller than walnut shells, and for a few decades in the 1400s and 1500s, elite clients, including Henry VIII, vied to own the miniature works. Yet no one seems to have recorded much about the sculptors techniques or even their names. In notes from the 1630s about an antique boxwood sphere with portraits of martyred saints, a Dutch art collector lamented, It is regrettable that the maker of this ingenious piece has not made himself known with any sign.

title: Echoes of an Exposition, and an Assassination
description: BUFFALO  THE Pan-American Exposition of 1901 was meant to celebrate Americas ingenuity and dominance over the Western Hemisphere  you know, when America was great again. Eight million people paid about 50 cents each to see buildings edged in light bulbs, sprawled across 350 acres at the suburban northern edge of this city. They also flocked to the nearby Niagara Falls to watch daredevils try to survive the rapids.

title: Review: In Trash Fire, a Familiar Formula Fails
description: For as long as I can remember, Ive been waiting for my parents to die, so I could commit suicide without feeling an overwhelming sense of guilt. With this opening line, Trash Fire lets you know that its writer-director is committed to commanding your attention. And also that he has seen, and admires, Goodfellas, which begins with a similar phrase.

title: Review: Dance Arrives From India. If Only It Could Stay Longer.
description: Youve been there? friends said in envy after Wednesdays Nrityagram Dance Ensemble performance in the Gerald W. Lynch Theater. Yes, Ive seen Nrityagram in India, at its home village near Bangalore and in Chennai  and yet the New York audience is in no way shortchanged. These are among the worlds greatest dancers; on Wednesday they gave as complete and fulfilling a vision of their art as any I have seen anywhere.

title: Megyn Kelly: By the Book
description: The Fox News anchor and author of Settle for More says Bridget Joness Diary reads like my own journals from pretty much every phase of my life and made me laugh so hard I cried.

title: Review: The Pickle Recipe Is a Sweet and Sour Caper
description: The pickles in The Pickle Recipe apparently have quite a kick. The movie, though, is pretty flavorless.

title: Former Napa Valley Winemaker Arrested in Fraud Scheme
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Federal prosecutors have brought eight fraud charges against Jeffry James Hill, a former Napa Valley winemaker and vineyard manager who was accused of stealing grapes and deceiving customers about the source and type of grapes in the wines he sold.

title: Young Adolescents as Likely to Die From Suicide as From Traffic Accidents
description: WASHINGTON  It is now just as likely for middle school students to die from suicide as from traffic accidents.

title: There Are No Wrong Thanksgiving Wines
description: No sooner did last Thanksgiving end than here we are again, deciding what to serve, how to cook it and what to drink. It worked out pretty well in 2015, didnt it?

title: The New York Times to Offer Open Access on Web and Apps for the Election
description: The New York Times is inviting readers to take advantage of its reporting, analysis and commentary from the lead-up through the aftermath of the 2016 election. Readers will have unlimited access to NYTimes.com for 72 hours from 12:01 a.m. ET on Monday, November 7 until 11:59 p.m. ET on Wednesday, November 9.

title: Delivering Fresh Attention to Josef Albers
description: Last year, abstracts by the German-born artist Josef Albers were selling for $150,000 to $250,000 at auction: not bad for a guy who died 40 years ago.

title: 5 Twombly Sculptures to Join His Paintings at Philadelphia Museum
description: The Philadelphia Museum of Art is one of the nations pre-eminent destinations for the work of Cy Twombly, who died in 2011 and whose monumental Homeric painting cycle Fifty Days at Iliam has been on permanent display there since 1989. Now, a group of five important bronze sculptures by Twombly, which he considered to be related to the paintings, will enter the museums collection, gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.

title: Rococo Bad Boy Rebels in Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant
description: Among the 18th centurys lesser-known declarations of independence was that of Jean-Honor Fragonard, the Rococo artist who was a rising star of the French Academy system when he decided, rather abruptly, that hed had enough of it. As we see in Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant  Works From New York Collections at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this rebellion took place largely on paper, in sprightly strokes of red chalk and splashes of brown wash that were, in form and spirit, the opposite of the history paintings he had been trained to produce.

title: The Paris Agreement on Climate Change Is Official. Now What?
description: PARIS  When the landmark Paris Agreement to address climate change officially goes into effect on Friday, the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe will be floodlit green to celebrate the occasion. Now comes the hard work: figuring out the details.

title: Review: The Prison in Twelve Landscapes Reveals the Invisible Tentacles of Mass Incarceration
description: In The Prison in Twelve Landscapes, a meditation on mass incarceration in the United States, the Canadian filmmaker Brett Story arranges a series of oblique, geographical vignettes into an unsettling mural of systemic damage.

title: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 9
description: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

title: New York Area Has the Nations 3 Worst Airports, Study Says
description: Those who fly to or from New York are fully accustomed to long security lines, labyrinthine paths to the terminal, flight delays, cancellations and other unpleasant happenings, not to mention the arduous or expensive journey to the airport itself.

title: Review: In Rainbow Time, Big Brothers Watching (and Lusting)
description: The engine of unpleasantness that drives Rainbow Time is a sex-crazed, 40-year-old virgin who answers to the nickname Shonzi (played by the writer and director, Linas Phillips). Denied sufficient oxygen at birth, Shonzi is developmentally delayed; hes also a bully whos not above using his mental status to guilt those around him into excusing his offensive behavior.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Ludlow 38, MINI/Goethe-Institut Curatorial Residencies 38 Ludlow Street, near Hester Street, Lower East Side Through Nov. 13

title: Review: My Dead Boyfriend Shares a Life, After the Fact
description: My Dead Boyfriend desperately tries to look and sound like a quirky indie hit, but thats not an achievable goal when you have an unlikable lead character indifferently rendered by a name star.

title: Review: We Are X Explores the Travails and Triumphs of a Rock Band
description: If We Are X proves anything, its that rock bands the world over can experience similar trials: acrimony and fatalities, but also, sometimes, glorious comebacks. This fascinating and assured documentary, directed by Stephen Kijak (Stones in Exile), tells the story of the group X Japan, a cultural institution in its native country, framed around the groups 2014 reunion concert at Madison Square Garden.

title: Review: Its 1996, and Jack Reacher Is Playing Nice With Others
description: Night School is the 21st book in Lee Childs Jack Reacher series, but whos counting? Most of us can merely marvel at the continuing allure of Reacher, think youve come a long way, baby and leave it at that.

title: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news  the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

title: This Weeks Movies: Nov. 3, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Doctor Strange, Hacksaw Ridge and Loving.

title: Review: Tending the Tempest Within in Peter and the Farm
description: The irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer and focus of Tony Stones wondrous documentary portrait, Peter and the Farm, is a man who contains multitudes. With his snowy beard and imperious bearing, Peter Dunning, at his most eloquent, conveys the authority of a biblical prophet but without a religious platform. As he surveys the 187-acre farm he has tended for more than 35 years, he also suggests a latter-day Prospero ruefully aware that his powers are waning.

title: The Voter Suppression Trail
description: Find out if your vote can survive the great, flawed adventure of American democracy.

title: Lending a Hand (and Fingers, and Fingertips) to Myths
description: The man in the photograph at right is angled slightly to one side, his arm curved and his fingers  held together, sharply separated from the thumb  pointing down into what appears to be an upside-down fish. Above him floats a bee, and a snake curls languorously over a branch, appearing to watch his activities with interest.

title: Review: In Loving, They Loved. A Segregated Virginia Did Not Love Them Back.
description: There are few movies that speak to the American moment as movingly  and with as much idealism  as Jeff Nicholss Loving, which revisits the era when blacks and whites were so profoundly segregated in this country that they couldnt always wed. Its a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, a married couple who were arrested in 1958 because he was white, she was not, and they lived in Virginia, a state that banned interracial unions. Virginia passed its first anti-miscegenation law in 1691, partly to prevent what it called spurious issue, or what most people just call children.

title: Cubs, Clinton, Mosul: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: The Trolls Embark on a High-Haired Rescue Mission
description: Exuberant, busy and sometimes funny, DreamWorks Animations Trolls is determined to amuse. You remember Trolls  not the rude lurkers online writing nasty remarks, but those little toys with round tummies, beatific expressions and abundant hair shooting upward. Here theyre players in a fairy-tale Cold War parable.

title: The Joys and Pains of Shared Birthdays
description: My friend and I have the same birthday, so I know he remembers when it is. In our 20s, we exchanged gifts. But as we aged, he stopped acknowledging my birthday (and is generally less likely to pick up the phone to keep in touch). This hurts my feelings. Still, he was incredibly supportive when my dad died last year. And if I ever have an important issue to talk through, he will spend as much time with me as I could possibly ask. So Im conflicted. And our shared birthday is coming up. What would you do?

title: Review: Dog Eat Dog Is a Pulpy Tale With Nasty, Bumbling Crooks
description: Despite its slim running time  barely over an hour and a half  Dog Eat Dog somehow feels like six different movies. The first one, which depicts an especially appalling double murder through the speedy, sickly colorful perspective of an extended drug binge, is probably the least effective of the batch. But it lets you know that the filmmakers are not coming at you from a benevolent place, and that impression never lets up.

title: A Blast from Campaigns Past ... A Grab Bag of Vintage Swag
description: IN an age of social media, it is easy to forget about old-fashioned presidential campaign memorabilia: posters, fliers, advertisements. The New-York Historical Society has not forgotten. Its exhibition of memorabilia from four presidential campaigns includes items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.

title: Review: Ivory. A Crime Story, or the Plight of African Elephants
description: The animals seem more humane than people in Ivory. A Crime Story. This roughly constructed yet passionate documentary isnt shy about showing the massacre of elephants or about calling out the groups implicit in the killings. That bluntness and courage usually overrides the uneven filmmaking.

title: Review: The Ivory Game Follows the Fight to Protect Elephants
description: After learning that a beloved wild elephant has been slaughtered by poachers, Craig Millar, a conservationist, wonders aloud how we got to this stage, as a human race, when we just lay waste to anything we value  anything we see just gets consumed. Still, he vows to fight on. I dont know if its ever going to make a difference, and if were ever going to do enough, but weve got to try.

title: No Laptop, No Phone, No Desk: UBS Reinvents the Work Space
description: LONDON  A desk is like a home away from home for many in the working world.

title: Election Day 2016: Teaching Ideas for Before and After the Votes Are Tallied
description: Updated, Nov. 15.

title: In Chicago, the Cubs Win Brings Baseball Unity, for Now
description: CHICAGO  Margaret Pinkston, a 69-year-old housekeeper who lives on the South Side, was waiting for a friend to bring over her breakfast tray at the Valois Cafeteria on Thursday morning when she leaned in conspiratorially. Im going to be honest, she said, lowering her voice. I dont know one person who wasnt rooting for the Cubs.

title: 1976 | Metropolitan Diary Opens Its Pages
description: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 28 through Nov. 1 with 1,561 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,333 said they were registered to vote.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll Finds Challenges for Next President
description: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump limp into Election Day locked in a tight race and saddled with voters unfavorable views of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll finds deep challenges awaiting the next president after a bruising election.

title: How States Moved Toward Stricter Voter ID Laws
description: Voters in seven states will be required to show photo identification at the polls this year.

title: A Narrower Majority for Republicans Could Widen the House Divide
description: WASHINGTON  The contest for control of the House of Representatives will probably yield an even more polarized chamber, leaving a smaller, more conservative Republican majority that may challenge the re-election of Paul D. Ryan as speaker and greet Hillary Clinton with a fresh round of investigations  whether she wins the White House or not.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

title: Retail Magic in the Meatpacking District
description: If you find yourself walking the Belgian-block streets of the meatpacking district, you are likely to be near a clothing boutique. It wasnt always that way. Jeffrey Kalinsky, the founder of the high-end chain Jeffrey, was something of a retail pioneer when he opened the second location of his namesake store in the neighborhood in 1999. Everyone thought it was radical, he said.

title: News of Charges in Price-Fixing Inquiry Sends Pharmaceuticals Tumbling
description: The generic drug industry was jolted on Thursday as shares of many major companies tumbled after a news report said that a federal inquiry into drug price-fixing was wider than previously believed and could lead to charges by the end of the year.

title: Guards Were Negligent in Fatal Encounter With New York Inmate, Judge Rules
description: Officers at the Clinton Correctional Facility used excessive force when they dragged a handcuffed inmate face down through prison corridors and then, when he was near death, provided faulty medical care, a judge in a New York State Court of Claims has ruled.

title: Beyoncs C.M.A. Awards Performance Becomes the Target of Backlash
description: On live television, Beyoncs improbable performance with the Dixie Chicks at the 50th annual Country Music Association Awards couldnt have gone more smoothly. With a giant band and brass section, the pop star blew through an extra twangy version of Daddy Lessons, the southern-fried track from her latest album, Lemonade, even working in a section of the Dixie Chicks own Long Time Gone in the middle. The Nashville crowd was on its feet.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: E. Lee Hennessee, a Leading Woman in Hedge Funds, Dies at 64
description: E. Lee Hennessee, a pioneering woman in the male-dominated hedge fund industry and the creator of one of the first indexes to track its secretive transactions, was found dead on Oct. 29 at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 64.

title: Classical Music Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

title: Parliaments Power Over Brexit
description: Someday the British  court ruling on Brexit may be studied as a milestone in parliamentary democracy. For now, though, it throws Britains fateful move to part ways with the European Union into considerable disarray.

title: Criminal Complaint in Shooting of Brooklyn Pizzeria Owner
description: Andres Fernandez was arrested Thursday in connection with the fatal shooting of Louis Barbati, an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, on June 30.

title: Walter Scotts Character Scrutinized in Trial of Officer Who Killed Him
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The judge faced the jury on Thursday morning and spoke solemnly about what many have called the greatest justice system ever created. Then the murder trial of a member of the most visible arm of the justice system  a police officer  began in earnest.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

title: That Supreme Court Stonewall May Not Crumble Anytime Soon
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Jeff Flake was startled a few months ago when a constituent pressed him on whether he was willing to hold up any Supreme Court nominee chosen by Hillary Clinton if she was elected president.

title: As Strollers Roll Through New York City Grit and Muck, an Industry Is Born
description: There is nothing more emblematic of New York City baby life than the beat-up stroller. In this walking city, strollers become homes on wheels, where babies and toddlers log long hours eating, napping and playing.

title: An Old Hand Once Again Tries His Luck at an Around-the-World Race
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass.  When Jos Luis Ugarte, the oldest sailor to finish the Vende Globe yacht race, finally arrived back on terra firma in 1993, he soberly pronounced the solo, round-the-world race an inhuman event that should be done no more than once in a lifetime.

title: Miriam Weinstein, Mother and Backbone of Original Miramax, Dies at 90
description: Miriam Weinstein, the mother of the filmmakers Harvey and Bob Weinstein and an inspiration for the name of their first film company, Miramax, died on Wednesday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 90.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

title: Sandwich and Half Sour
description: Dear Diary:

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

title: Fox News Lineup Begins to Take Shape
description: Much is yet to be determined about the future of Fox News, especially with the contracts of the star anchors Megyn Kelly and Bill OReilly soon to run out.

title: Wells Fargo Faces Scrutiny for Black Marks on Ex-Employee Files
description: Three senators fired at Wells Fargos new chief executive with fresh ammunition on Thursday: the hundreds of termination notices the bank filed with an industry overseer over the last five years as employees left the company in connection with its sales scandal.

title: Obama Brings ESPNs Cmon, Man! to the Campaign Trail
description: WASHINGTON  Cmon, man!

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

title: Kay Starr, Hillbilly Singer With Crossover Appeal, Dies at 94
description: Kay Starr, the self-described hillbilly singer who crisscrossed jazz, country, pop, blues and rock n roll in the 1950s with hits like Wheel of Fortune and Rock and Roll Waltz, died on Thursday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

title: Sorting Through the Clinton Email Case and What the F.B.I.s Options Are
description: WASHINGTON  A week ago, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, jolted the presidential race by sending a letter to Congress saying the bureau had discovered new emails that might be relevant to Hillary Clintons use of a private server. The disclosure set off widespread criticism of Mr. Comey and unleashed a hurricane of news about Mrs. Clintons family foundation, Russia and F.B.I. infighting. Lets sort it all out.

title: Time to Move the Standing Rock Pipeline
description: President Obama has pointed a way out of a dangerous standoff over an oil pipeline being built in North Dakota. He told an interviewer on Tuesday that the Army Corps of Engineers was looking for a new pipeline route, presumably away from the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, whose members and allies have been protesting the project for months, saying it threatens the tribes sacred lands and water supply.

title: Around Town for Nov. 4-10
description: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

title: At Trader Joes, Good Cheer May Hide Complaints
description: To explain their infatuation with Trader Joes, fans of the offbeat grocery chain typically cite three factors: low prices, an appealing selection of high-end products and, perhaps above all, irrepressibly friendly employees.

title: Donald Trumps Impeachment Threat
description: Donald Trump and other embattled Republican candidates are resorting to a particularly bizarre and dangerous tactic in the closing days of the campaign  warning that they may well seek to impeach Hillary Clinton if she wins, or, short of that, tie her up with endless investigations and other delaying tactics.

title: Penn State Faces Record Fine in Sandusky-Related Case
description: Four years after Jerry Sandusky, a former Penn State assistant football coach, was convicted of sexually abusing 10 young boys, the federal government is seeking to fine the university nearly $2.4 million for failing to alert the public about Mr. Sanduskys conduct and other campus dangers.

title: C. E. Morgan Among Winners of $50,000 Kirkus Book Prizes
description: C.E. Morgan, Susan Faludi and Jason Reynolds were honored on Thursday at the third annual Kirkus Prizes ceremony in Austin, Tex. Each prize comes with an award of $50,000.

title: Mayor de Blasios Donors Are Avoiding Democrats in State Senate Races
description: Two years ago, Alex Lodde, a Texas transportation magnate, made his first political donation in New York a meaningful one: He gave $100,000 to a small county political committee in the Hudson Valley to support an all-out effort by Mayor Bill de Blasio to deliver control of the State Senate to his fellow Democrats.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

title: Harvard Cancels Rest of Mens Soccer Season Over Lewd Ratings of Female Players
description: Harvard announced on Thursday that it was canceling the rest of the season for its mens soccer team after university officials uncovered what they described as a widespread practice of the teams players rating the schools female players in sexually explicit terms.

title: You Might Be Paying Too Much for Your Chicken
description: Beef prices at grocery stores are lower. So, too, are pork prices. But chicken? Steady as she goes.

title: Longtime Prospect Park Carousel Operator to Stop Making His Rounds
description: For the past 26 years, when children have raced through the doors of the carousel at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, Lucio Schiavone has gently called out, Tickets, tickets please. Once they have all settled, he rings a brass bell, presses his palm against a big red button and then perches himself on a tall stool to watch.

title: Seeing the New York City Marathon From the Other Side of the Starting Line
description: On Sunday, Mary Wittenberg, the former president of New York Road Runners, will tour New York Citys five boroughs on foot  one of about 50,000 entrants in the New York City Marathon, a race she directed for 10 years but has never run. Wittenberg, 54, is a longtime resident of the Upper East Side, where she lives with her husband and two sons. Since taking over Virgin Sport, a company started by Richard Branson, in 2015, she has learned to merge training trips with work trips. A onetime competitive marathoner, Wittenberg spoke about preparing once again for the other side of the starting line.

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 4-10
description: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

title: Much Is on the Line for California Chrome at the Breeders Cup
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  There is no racetrack on earth with a backside kitchen as chic as Clockers Corner at Santa Anita Park. This open-air bistro beneath the rouge-tipped San Gabriel Mountains is where the toned and the tan bask each morning in eternal sunshine as tens of millions of dollars of horse flesh circles the oval before them.

title: Cowardly Killings of Officers Strike a Raw Nerve in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  For law enforcement officers here, it feels like a still-raw wound being torn open anew. Less than eight months after a drunken driver killed two police officers in a fiery crash, two other officers were shot to death in separate episodes on Wednesday.

title: Cubs Clinched Title Before Baseballs Largest TV Audience in Decades
description: After Games 5 and 6 of this years World Series were seen by about 23 million viewers each, many began to wonder: How many more people would watch the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians play Game 7 on Wednesday night?

title: Clinton Pushes Minority Turnout as Trump Tries to Rally His Base
description: Saturating swing states with powerful campaign surrogates and mobilizing a vast field organization, Hillary Clinton on Thursday intensified her public attacks on Donald J. Trump as a threat to minorities in the hope of driving them to the polls in decisive numbers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is why I came here: to break the goat or the black cat or God knows what somebody else wants to talk about. Its over.

title: As Trump Ally, Rudy Giuliani Boasts of Ties to F.B.I.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, seemed in a giddy mood when he was interviewed last week on the Fox & Friends morning television show.

title: San Francisco Files Lawsuit Against Sinking Millennium Tower
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Five years ago, when Frank Jernigan, a retired Google software engineer, and his husband bought a 50th-floor apartment in downtown San Francisco for $4 million, they felt on top of the world. And judging by the commanding view of San Francisco Bay from the plate glass windows of their living room, they were.

title: Well, Seor Kaine, Hablaste Espaol Muy Bien
description: PHOENIX  No hablo espaol perfectamente, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia told an audience of 150 guests here on Thursday, during a political event billed as historic by the Hillary Clinton campaign. For the first time, a candidate on a United States presidential ticket delivered a speech entirely in Spanish, a language that is a synonym for immigration in this state.

title: Something No One Can Sing
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Ah, our young constructors ... they grow up so quickly, dont they?

title: Review: The Jobs Are Gone in Sweat. So Are Peoples Hopes.
description: In Lynn Nottages scorching play Sweat, the bonds among a group of working-class friends and family are frayed to the breaking point by the pressure of an eroding economic future. Keenly observed and often surprisingly funny  but ultimately heartbreaking  the work traces the roots of a tragedy with both forensic psychological detail and embracing compassion. Ms. Nottage, a Pulitzer Prize winner for Ruined, is writing at the peak of her powers, and the superb cast and the director, Kate Whoriskey, rise to the occasion.

title: Missing South Carolina Woman Found in Metal Container
description: A South Carolina woman who was reported missing with her boyfriend in August was found alive on Thursday in a metal storage container on a remote 100-acre property and a registered sex offender was arrested in connection with her disappearance, according to officials and news media accounts.

title: Turkey Detains Leaders of Kurdish Opposition Party
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish police detained the two co-leaders of Turkeys main Kurdish opposition party and several of its lawmakers on Friday during early-morning raids as part of a counterterrorism investigation, the state news media reported.

title: Oilers Equal Rangers Speed but Cant Match Their Stamina
description: Cam Talbot, the Edmonton Oilers goaltender, stayed down on one knee for a while, stunned after Rick Nash had scored what proved to be the winning goal for the Rangers with 1 minute 21 seconds left in the third period on Thursday night.

title: 12 Indelible Images From the 2016 Campaign
description: Photographers have shot tens of thousands of images for The New York Times and logged hundreds of thousands of miles on the presidential campaign trail since early 2015. Here are 12 of their most memorable photographs.

title: South Korean Leader Says She Will Submit to Scandal Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye said Friday that she was willing to submit to questioning by prosecutors investigating a scandal that has engulfed her administration, saying she would sever ties with an old friend accused of using their relationship to extort money from businesses.

title: On the Trail: Thursday, Nov. 3
description: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton both held rallies in North Carolina.

title: Fizzling Offense Hurts Manchester Uniteds Europa Hopes
description: Manchester Uniteds attacking problems continued Thursday in the clubs 2-1 loss to host Fenerbahce in the Europa League, leaving it at risk of a group-stage exit.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Melania Trump, Brexit, Turkey: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Whats on TV Friday: The Crown and President Obama on Real Time With Bill Maher
description: Make it a royal evening with The Crown, starring Claire Foy as a young Queen Elizabeth II, and The Queen, with Helen Mirren as the ruler in her later years. Meanwhile, President Obama talks with Bill Maher.

title: Dick Clark Productions to Be Sold to Chinese Company for $1 Billion
description: HONG KONG  Some of Americas most glittery TV spectacles will have a Chinese owner.

title: 1 Series. 7 Games. 15 Columns.
description: A collection of On Baseball columns from the 2016 World Series.

title: The Week in Pictures: Nov. 4, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: Word + Quiz: adjuration
The Week in Pictures: Nov. 4, 2016
description: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

title: The Post-Truth Presidency
description: We can say with absolute certainty that the Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year spell of futility and won the World Series. The Curse of the Billy Goat is dead. We also know with absolute certainty that on the dawn following the last out, the sun rose over Chicago, my dads hometown, at 7:26 a.m.

title: The Banality of Change
description: A few weeks ago I met a guy in Idaho who was absolutely certain that Donald Trump would win this election. He was wearing tattered, soiled overalls, missing a bunch of teeth and was unnaturally skinny. He was probably about 50, but his haggard face looked 70. He was getting by aimlessly as a handyman.

title: Who Broke Politics?
description: As far as anyone can tell, Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House  and the leader of whats left of the Republican establishment  isnt racist or authoritarian. He is, however, doing all he can to make a racist authoritarian the most powerful man in the world. Why? Because then he could privatize Medicare and slash taxes on the wealthy.

title: Dalai Lama: Behind Our Anxiety, the Fear of Being Unneeded
description: In many ways, there has never been a better time to be alive. Violence plagues some corners of the world, and too many still live under the grip of tyrannical regimes. And although all the worlds major faiths teach love, compassion and tolerance, unthinkable violence is being perpetrated in the name of religion.

title: Gary Johnson, Queen Maker
description: With just a few days before Election Day and all eyes fixed on the two leading candidates, its easy to overlook a remarkable fact: The Libertarian candidate for president, Gary Johnson, may tilt the election for Hillary Clinton. And if he does, it wouldnt be the first time  not even close. The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.

title: Are Voting Booth Selfies Fun or Dangerous?
Suket Dhir, Mens Wear Designer, From Delhi to the World
description: NEW DELHI  In a stifling office on the second floor of an anonymous building along a dusty lane in Lado Sarai  the new hub for young artists in a corner of the southwestern part of this capital city  a 38-year-old mens wear designer Vogue.com has called a global fashion superstar in the making sat in semidarkness.

title: Jungle on Fire: Migrant Camp Destroyed
description: French authorities demolished the sprawling camp in Calais, France, last week, and hundreds of migrants are now camping out in tents in Paris. Step inside the Jungle as it was razed and burned.

title: Questions for: How the Internet Is Loosening Our Grip on the Truth
description: Article: How the internet Is Loosening Our Grip on the Truth

title: Secret Spaces
description: A recent article in the Real Estate section revealed some of New Yorks Secret Doors and Hidden Rooms, one of which is picture here.

title: The 10.23.16 Issue
description: RE: THE PLAYBORHOOD

title: Has a Teacher Ever Changed Your Mind-Set?
description: Sometimes we develop ideas about ourselves as a student that are at best, unhelpful, and at worst, destructive. For example, we may think were just not good at a subject, like math. Or we may assume, no matter how hard we try, that well fail anyway. Some studies show that teachers can have a lasting impact on students academic futures by changing their mind-sets.

title: My U-Turn From Isolation to Intimacy
description: There is a moment when your child gets too adolescent to cuddle. For me, that moment arrived when my 14-year-old son, Joe, headed to theater camp for a month. He was so eager to get there, he asked me to drop him off at the entrance. But there are papers that need signing when you entrust your child to strangers. Nonetheless, I was hoping for a goodbye hug.

title: Using Airbnb to Sample Someone Elses Style
description: Shirley Criddle and her husband, Markus Flatscher, are 20th-century design enthusiasts. Their Chicago home is filled with vintage furniture by the likes of Oscar Niemeyer and Paul McCobb, and Mr. Flatscher idolizes Frank Lloyd Wright, whom he considers one of the greatest architects of all time.

title: An American in a Strange Land
description: I heard it often, traveling around Europe as a journalist. I even heard it from an immigration officer at Gatwick Airport outside London, who teased me as he looked at my passport. I was an American abroad, which meant being held accountable for the strange and fevered state of my homeland, which meant facing some version of the question What is going on in the United States? Sometimes the query had an air of schadenfreude, but just as often there was a hint of real concern. The rest of the world already seemed to be going off the rails. It couldnt afford to have America follow.

title: Where Did My Supermarket Go?
description: In New York City, distance is measured in blocks. The number of blocks a New Yorker has to trek lugging an armful of groceries could mean the difference between a great neighborhood and a crummy one.

title: How to Busk
description: I would recommend taking a weekend, if not a few, to walk around the area you want to perform in, to see what other street performers are doing, Colin Huggins says. After taking in the competition, run your idea by a few friends. Huggins, who is 38 and played piano for the Joffrey Ballet School during its practices in New York, now plays a baby grand, which he pushes on a dolly over the streets of Greenwich Village. Come up with something unique, he says. People who come to New York, they want to see something unique.

title: Presidential Election: Beyonc and Jay Z Join Hillary Clinton
description: The final Friday of the 2016 election cycle follows days of musical and political celebrities campaigning on Hillary Clintons behalf, including a concert with Jay Z and Beyonc on Friday in Cleveland.

title: Beleaguered
description: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

title: Last Economic Snapshot Before the Election Shows Healthy Job Growth
description: The last time the unemployment rate was running this low was in early 2008. But by Election Day that year, the economy was in sad shape and getting worse by every measure. Hundreds of thousands of jobs were vanishing, housing prices were plunging, paychecks were shrinking and credit was tight.

title: Billboard, Souvenir, Metaphor: The Many Uses of a German Beer Coaster
description: Breweries provide them, waiters keep running tabs on them, tourists collect them, and this summer a local government repurposed them as political billboards to spread messages of tolerance.

title: As Deer Chew Up Suburbs, Some Say a Good Fence Is the Best Defense
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  Given her homes location near the corner of Deertrack Lane and Whitetail Road, it should come as no surprise that Ellen Shapiro, an ardent gardener, had a serious deer problem.

title: Afghanistan Itself Is Now Taking In the Most Afghan Migrants
description: SAMARKHEL, Afghanistan  There is one country in the world that is now taking in more Afghan migrants than all the countries in Europe and South Asia put together this year.

title: A Militia Gets Battle Ready for a Gun-Grabbing Clinton Presidency

title: Teaching With: 11 Excellent Reasons Not to Vote?
description: Some 93 million eligible American citizens did not vote during the 2012 presidential election. How many tens of millions of people will choose not to vote in this years election? What might be their reasons?

title: G.O.P. Secretary of State Fund-Raising and Ballot Initiative Project
description: In 2015, the Republican State Leadership Committee  which includes secretaries of state, who are charged with ensuring fair and accurate elections  began a program to defeat liberal ballot initiatives on topics like the minimum wage, and to raise money from corporations that also wanted to kill these efforts. Here is a look at the push.

title: These Officials Help Write Ballot Questions. Companies Write Them Checks.
description: WASHINGTON  Big-money corporate lobbying has reached into one of the most obscure corners of state government: the offices of secretaries of state, the people charged with running elections impartially.

description: They just keep coming. Wells Fargo, already reeling from a scandal over fake accounts and a settlement over home appraisal overcharges, has been hit with yet more accusations.

title: A Venice Restaurant With Its Ethos Right in Its Name
description: There is no coyness to the ethos of Local, a modern new restaurant in Venice  its right there in the English-language name. Everything that Local serves originates nearby, or at least has a Venetian twist, including the chef, Matteo Tagliapietra, who is from the nearby island of Burano.

title: Going to the Emergency Room Without Leaving the Living Room
description: For a while, paramedics were rushing Maria Vitale to the emergency room at Long Island Jewish Medical Center every few weeks.

description: From $149

title: Whales Can Really Rock With Their Mellow Songs
description: When a whale sings, it fills the sea with more than just serene sounds. It also sends vibrations coursing through the water like a speaker with the bass turned way up.

description: Half of all voters in the nation live in a county that was won in a landslide.

description: For Marlena Baldacci and Ryan Militana, their first meeting as 16-year-olds at the Lewis School of Driving in New Canaan, would leave a lasting impression, leading them to marriage years later.

title: Seeking a Drivers License Led to a Marriage License
description: The road from the first to a second kiss shared between Marlena Baldacci and Ryan Militana, a stretch of 14 years, began with a drivers education class.

description: In what has mostly been a demoralizing presidential race, there has been at least one reliable bright spot: Bad Lip Reading.

description: So Donald Trump has said the following in Florida: Im honored to have the greatest temperament that anyones ever had.

description: I knew it would be bad; the only question was how bad.

description: They are too young to vote, but old enough to follow the news. For teenage girls, this gender bomb of an election is happening just as they are starting to form their identities as young women.

title: Deirdre Quinn: If a Meeting Starts at 9, Be There at 8
description: This interview with Deirdre Quinn, chief executive of Lafayette 148 New York, a womens fashion company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Want Co-Workers to Vote Your Way? Then Stop Pestering Them
description: Every four years, I notice a dramatic increase in personal disclosure at the office. Co-workers who are usually reserved about nonwork matters suddenly begin expressing their political beliefs and singing the praises of their preferred presidential candidates.

title: Sting to Perform at Reopening of Bataclan a Year After Paris Attacks
description: The British musician Sting has announced that he will perform at the Nov. 12 reopening of the Bataclan, almost a year to the day after a terrorist attack at the Paris concert hall killed 90 people.

title: Teenagers in The Times | October, 2016
description: Welcome to the October edition of Teenagers in The Times, our monthly round up of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. You can find our next installment on Dec. 2.

title: The Walls in Our Heads
description: Even though Donald J. Trump took a brief break from stumping the other day to open a new Trump hotel, in Washington, D.C., he has rarely paused in nearly 18 months of political campaigning in selling the American electorate hard on his latest, most ambitious, mega-development: the Wall. As if lifted from a real estate brochure, the adjectives, stitched together, soothe and seduce: An impenetrable, physical, tall, powerful, beautiful, southern  the southern rather innocuously tucked in, like a house advertising southern exposure  border wall.

title: How the First Bad Santa Boozed Down the Chimney
description: When Bob Weinstein first received the script for Bad Santa, he felt that a gift had been dropped in his lap. Universal had set the project aside, and Mr. Weinstein snapped it up for his company at the time, Miramax: I asked a Universal executive, Whyd you guys pass on it? And he said, It was the most foul, disgusting, misogynistic, anti-Christmas, anti-children thing we could imagine. Mr. Weinstein recalled. Thats exactly why I bought it.

title: Hollywood Holiday Habits: Big Games, Small Gifts and Other Joys
description: We asked stars and filmmakers about their holiday traditions. Here are edited excerpts from their answers:
