description: The actress Geneva Carr refers to her light-filled two-bedroom co-op as the home that AT&T built. She played a woman obsessed with rollover minutes in a series of mobile-phone commercials that aired from 2007 to 2009. And they afforded me an adorable apartment in Harlem, said Ms. Carr, 45.

title: What I Love | Geneva Carr
description: The actress, a star of the new CBS drama Bull, lives in a co-op in Harlem.

title: Noma Chefs Next Place to Pop Up: Mexico
description: Ren Redzepi was already familiar with hard-shell tacos out of the box, a fairly common product in Denmark, the taco-deficient nation where he lives and runs the influential restaurant Noma. But those arent the tacos that changed his life.

title: The Trump Transition
description: Hes hired.

title: Andre Ward and Sergey Kovalev to Meet in a Title Fight Long Overdue
description: Imagine if the Golden State Warriors and the Cleveland Cavaliers had never played on national television until they met in last seasons N.B.A. finals, or that the basketball stars Stephen Curry and LeBron James had never gotten to play in an All-Star Game.

title: Readers Debate the Merits of Social Media Before and After the Election
description: Twitter is hardly the only platform people are sick of using.

title: Voyeur | Sconces
description: The sconces of the city are often overlooked and for good reason: You have to watch where you are going. But many are surprisingly handsome.

description: Gilbert Cruz, The Timess television editor, talks TV with Margaret Lyons and John Koblin.

title: What Sci-Fi Show Should I Try Next?
description: Are you trying to figure out what to watch next? (Or maybe what TV show to give up on completely?) Watching is here to help. Send your questions to watching@nytimes.com.

title: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: Buckingham Palace, With Its 775 Rooms, Will Be Renovated
description: LONDON  The boilers are shot, the water pipes sag and the 60-year-old cabling is a fire hazard.

title: 2,500 Years of Indian History in One Book
description: INCARNATIONSA History of India in Fifty LivesBy Sunil KhilnaniIllustrated. 449 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: The American Battle Over War Powers
description: WAGING WARThe Clash Between Presidents and Congress 1776 to ISISBy David J. BarronIllustrated. 560 pp. Simon & Schuster. $30.

title: Germany Buys Thomas Manns Los Angeles Home
description: The German government has bought the Los Angeles home where the novelist Thomas Mann lived from 1942 to 1952.

title: The Chosen at 50
description: Chaim Potoks The Chosen, about the intense, complicated friendship between two Jewish boys who meet in 1940s Brooklyn, is one of a select few novels to consistently remain on school reading lists across the country. A new edition has just been published to commemorate the books 50th anniversary, which officially comes in 2017.

title: The Kind of Car Insurer That Gives Consumers the Best Value
description: Are people better off when they buy things from companies that dont have public shareholders they need to please?

title: Race in America After the Great Migration
description: A century ago, almost all black Americans lived in the South, largely in rural areas. By 1970, most lived outside the South, a great many in Northern and Western industrial cities. Driven, in part, by hopes for greater economic opportunity, millions of black migrants made this move. Did they find what they were looking for?

title: Paperback Row
description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: When to Leave on Your Thanksgiving Drive
description: When should you leave for your Thanksgiving drive in order to avoid getting stuck in traffic with the tens of millions of people on the road? That depends on where you are, according to Google. Based on last years travel patterns from Google Maps users, the best day to leave is the Sunday before Thanksgiving, though the time varies. If youve already missed that window, never fear: Google has also compiled the worst time to leave.

title: An Embassy in Jerusalem? Trump Promises, but So Did Predecessors
description: JERUSALEM  Americas top diplomat in Jerusalem lives in an elegant three-story stone house first built by a German Lutheran missionary in 1868, a short walk from the historic Old City. But he is not an ambassador and the mission is a consulate, not an embassy.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Michael Chabons Moonglow
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: The Story Behind This Weeks Best Sellers
description: Bloc Party: For a supposedly neglected cohort, the white working class sure has made its presence felt lately on the best-seller list. (And in, you know, the voting booth. But this column is about books, not politics, so lets take a deep breath and open our chakras; you can turn to the Op-Ed page if you really want to get riled up again.) This year the historian Nancy Isenberg spent 11 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list with White Trash, tracing the role of poor white people from colonial times to the present. Then came J.D. Vance with Hillbilly Elegy, a blend of memoir and sociology thats still selling well  after 16 weeks, its No.3 in hardcover nonfiction. Now heres Arlie Russell Hochschild, a Berkeley sociologist who got to know Tea Party types in Louisiana for the National Book Award finalist Strangers in Their Own Land, new at No.14 on the hardcover nonfiction list.

title: How Van Jones Became a Star of the 2016 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Last Thursday, Van Jones couldnt even buy a tuna wrap here without a woman in her late 20s walking up to him to ask for a selfie. Two minutes later, the Argentine woman behind the counter gave him a thumbs up.

title: The Images in Billy Lynn? Razor Sharp. Your Eyes? Bewildered.
description: Ang Lees new film, Billy Lynns Long Halftime Walk, contains sights perhaps never so vividly rendered in a movie. When bullet casings fly from a machine gun, each one is clearly visible rather than appearing in a blur. When Billy Lynn (Joe Alwyn), a soldier on leave from Iraq, tears up at the national anthem or experiences battle flashbacks during the smoke bombs of a Destinys Child performance, the emotions in his eyes register with uncommon clarity.

title: Protests Erupt in Peru Ahead of Asia-Pacific Economic Meeting
description: LIMA, Peru  Hundreds of state workers have marched through the streets of Lima, the capital of Peru, because they have not been paid. Fishermen have protested being told they could not fish, complaining that they have no other means to feed their families. And residents living near Machu Picchu shut down trains to the famous Inca ruins, saying that the company operating the railway is unresponsive to commuters relying on it to get to work.

title: 650 Harvard Business School Women Assail Stephen Bannon
description: To the Editor:

title: Who First Farmed Potatoes? Archaeologists in Andes Find Evidence
description: Nobody knows precisely what the Pilgrims first Thanksgiving feast looked like. According to primary sources, there was fowl (likely including wild turkeys), venison and cornmeal for sure. Possible side dishes were cranberries, pumpkin and stuffing made with onions, nuts and herbs.

title: Ackman Admits Mistake, but Chipotle Bet Could Be Another
description: What should we make of the outspoken defense offered by William A. Ackman of his hedge funds awful performance in the last two years? Has he, as he claimed at last weeks DealBook conference, learned the hard lesson of his disastrous 2015 investment in Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, which has cost his investors billions of dollars?

title: The Rule of Law in Hong Kong
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Give an I.R.A. to Children Without Giving Up Control
description: Most people spend whatever they have saved in their individual retirement accounts in the years after they stop working. If theyre fortunate, they have enough to last.

title: Privatizing Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: Zika Is No Longer a Global Emergency, W.H.O. Says
description: The World Health Organization declared an end to its global health emergency over the spread of the Zika virus on Friday, prompting dismay from some public health experts confronting the epidemic.

title: An Anti-Muslim Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: The Playlist: Nicki Minaj Flips Mannequins Into Barbies
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

title: Ford Move, Cited as Victory by Trump, Has No Effect on U.S. Jobs
description: Judging from a couple of Twitter messages by President-elect Donald J. Trump, he had scored a hard-won victory for American autoworkers by persuading Ford Motor to keep a Lincoln plant in Louisville, Ky., rather than move it to Mexico.

title: Dr. Denton Cooley, Whose Pioneering Heart Surgery Set Off a 40-Year Medical Feud, Dies at 96
description: Dr. Denton A. Cooley, the renowned surgeon who was the first to implant a totally artificial heart in a patient and in the process set off one of medicines greatest feuds, died on Friday at his home in Houston. He was 96.

title: Will Women Still Want to Run?
description: After the ugliest campaign in recent memory, would any woman in her right mind want to run for president again?

title: Russell Simmons: For Black Comedians, Its Hollywood So White
description: When All Def Comedy, my showcase for up-and-coming black comedians, had its premiere on Nov. 12 on HBO, it brought back memories of Def Comedy Jam, its 90s-era predecessor. In The New York Times, Jason Zinoman wrote an appreciation of the old show, calling it trailblazing and filled with a staggering amount of talent. While I liked a lot of what he said, he lacked insight on one point: how important a platform like this still is. The new show arrives in a very different comedy climate, he wrote, adding, There are more platforms today and noting that the scene is less segregated.

title: N.F.L. Schedule: Who We Think Will Win in Week 11
description: The Cowboys are sitting fat, not because theyve feasted on cornfed portions of the N.F.L.s top sirloin, but because theyve binged on junk food like the Cleveland Browns and the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Review: Maybe Later, Santa. The Holidays Are for High Kicking.
description: Obviously, seasonal cheer floods Christmas Spectacular Starring the Radio City Rockettes: It coats every second of the production, from the scores wall-to-wall holiday hits to the ubiquitous presence of a certain portly, red-suited gentleman.

title: Billy the Kid: The Novel
description: THE KIDBy Ron Hansen301 pp. Scribner. $26.

title: Amos Oz on His Novel Judas, Which Challenges Views of a Traitor
description: Amos Oz was 8 the first time he was called a traitor.

title: Review: Memory Rings. Forget About It.
description: Memory is notoriously unreliable, so I am hoping that mine quickly expunges any recollection of Memory Rings, an obscure, whimsy-sprinkled dance-theater work about, well, Im not sure what. Trees, basically, and maybe why we should all hug them before they fall to the forces of human depredation.

title: A Baked Frittata to Feed Out-of-Town Guests
description: Whether served for breakfast, carried to the office for nibbling at ones desk, carted to the beach for al fresco sustenance, or used as the basis for an ad-lib dinner, a frittata is an abidingly easy, satisfying choice. Good eggs and a few tasty additions are all you need.

title: Markets Sent a Strong Signal on Trump ... Then Changed Their Minds
description: The stock markets turbulent response to the election of Donald J. Trump  first down, then up  presents an interesting quandary: Was the election result good or bad for investors?

title: Ivanka Trumps Presence at Meeting With Japans Leader Raises Questions
description: WASHINGTON  The potential for conflicts of interest between President-elect Donald J. Trump and his familys business ventures emerged again Thursday evening, when a photograph was distributed that showed his daughter Ivanka at a meeting between Mr. Trump and the prime minister of Japan.

title: Friday Mailbag: No More Politics. Just Kidding.
description: Last week, our first Friday mailbag was mostly election themed, with Donald Trumps surprise victory occupying most readers minds. This week has been no different: The number of letters only increased over the weekend and during the first half of the week, coming in  at their highest rate  at around 500 per day.

title: Silenced for Decades, Victims of Despotism Air Torture Claims in Tunisia
description: TUNIS  Mothers trembled with anger demanding justice for sons shot dead during protests that ushered in democracy. Former prisoners described being tortured, humiliated and forced to engage in homosexual acts. The abuses, they recalled, were deliberate, sadistic and aimed to break them.

title: Concerns About Conflicts and Nepotism Under Donald Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Philharmonics Next Leader Gives a Taste of Things to Come
description: Great anticipation hovered over Thursday evenings New York Philharmonic concert at David Geffen Hall. It was the first program to be led by the Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden since the announcement in January that he would succeed Alan Gilbert as music director.

title: George Condos Confrontation
description: A look inside the sprawling exhibition at Museum Berggruen.

title: A New Show That Puts George Condo Next to Picasso
description: When Udo Kittelmann, the director of Berlins Nationalgalerie, initially floated the idea of an exhibition that would position George Condos work against pieces from Museum Berggruens 20th-century art collection, the American painter had some doubts. Udo said, You make so many modernist references, but I didnt want to have a George Condo at random sitting next to a Picasso or a Matisse, Condo remembers. Youd see the absolute differences, as much as it appears to be referential. Kittelmann spent two full days rummaging through the artists New York storage space, finally landing on a nontraditional approach, and convinced Condo to go along with it: The curator cleared out the museums 28 rooms, installed his pick of 118 Condo paintings, drawings, collages and sculptures  most never shown before  and then reinstalled parts of the Berggruens collection accordingly.

title: Review: A Taste of Things to Come Is a Recipe for Catchy Musical Theater
description: If youre a theatergoer who prefers to stay in your seat during intermission, rethink that philosophy for A Taste of Things to Come, the breezy musical at York Theater Company. Theres something in the lobby you ought to see.

title: Mourning the Greats: Leonard Cohen, Leon Russell and Mose Allison
description: This year, the world of pop music has been thick with mourning  Prince, David Bowie, Merle Haggard, and too many more. And just in the last couple of weeks, more deaths of towering figures: the melancholy poet Leonard Cohen, in the throes of a late-life creative surge; the revered songwriter and session player Leon Russell; and Mose Allison, a hybridizer of bebop and blues with a wicked streak in his lyrics.

title: Elon Musk Faces Epic Juggling Act After Tesla-SolarCity Deal
description: Tesla Motors eager shareholders have made Elon Musk too cool to fail. Their decision to back the Silicon Valley billionaires quixotic $2.6 billion bid for SolarCity, a solar-panel company run by his cousin, sets up an epic 2017 juggling act. A lot could go wrong as Mr. Musk tries to integrate the two companies without compromising on Teslas ambitious production targets. Indulgent investors, though, are likely to give him a pass.

title: Arts and Science
description: Last weeks galas included the Whitney Museum, the French Heritage Society and the New York Hall of Science.

title: Arts and Science
description: The Museum of Modern Art honored Tom Hanks at its annual film benefit on Tuesday, which was presented by Chanel. The Whitney Museum of American Art held its Art Party on Tuesday. The French Heritage Society hosted a Proust Ball-themed party at the Plaza hotel on Wednesday. And the New York Hall of Science had an awards dinner at 583 Park Avenue on Wednesday.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Ahilan Arulanantham
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Ahilan Arulanantham, director of advocacy and legal director at the ACLU of Southern California and a 2016 MacArthur Genius Grant Recipient. He shares his list exclusively with T.

title: 6 Great New Picture Books for Kids
description: The best of this seasons picture books, chosen by Maria Russo, The New York Times Book Reviews childrens books editor.

title: Your A.T.M. Is Covered in Microbes, but Mostly Harmless
description: Whenever you withdraw money from an automated teller machine, the A.T.M. deposits microbes onto you.

title: Fifth Avenue in Front of Trump Tower Will Stay Open, de Blasio Says
description: The stretch of Fifth Avenue in front of President-elect Donald J. Trumps home in Trump Tower will remain open to vehicle traffic for the foreseeable future, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said on Friday.

title: Devils Look for Offense in Taylor Halls Absence
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Any enthusiasm generated by the surprising start to the Devils N.H.L. season was dulled by the announcement Wednesday that their leading scorer, Taylor Hall, would be out of the lineup for at least three weeks after undergoing surgery to repair a torn meniscus in his left knee.

title: Review: No Blood Spilled at This Concert (Though It Seemed So)
description: Before he played the first encore to his brilliant solo piano recital at Carnegie Hall, Behzod Abduraimov pulled out a handkerchief and wiped down the keys.

title: Review: DanceNoise, Lamenting AIDS and Armed With Fresh Blood
description: They threw dog snacks on the floor, stripped to nothing and toasted with glasses full of fake blood, which they poured on their naked bodies. They held up banners  one said Silence, the other = Death  and then used them to wipe each other clean.

title: Trumps New Hard-Line Aides Worry Muslims, but Some See an Upside
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Many Muslims in the Middle East reacted with a mix of fear, caution, suspicion and scorn on Friday to President-elect Donald J. Trumps appointments of aides with hostile views toward Islam.

title: Bitcoin Users Who Evade Taxes Are Sought by the I.R.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Internal Revenue Service is on the hunt for people who used Bitcoin to evade taxes.

title: Gilbert Cruz: How The Times Covers Television
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: GaymerX Offers a Safe Space for L.G.B.T. Gamers
description: The convention, which took place last weekend in Manhattan, celebrated gender diversity in gaming.

title: L.G.B.T. Gamers Huddle for a Postelection Reality Check
description: Matt Conn didnt think much of it when he scheduled GaymerX East, a convention celebrating sexuality and gender diversity in gaming, for the weekend after the election. But as the event drew near, he realized that the real world would be inescapable, even in fantasy.

title: Donald Trump Agrees to Pay $25 Million in Trump University Settlement
description: Donald J. Trump has reversed course and agreed on Friday to pay $25 million to settle a series of lawsuits stemming from his defunct for-profit education venture, Trump University, finally putting to rest fraud allegations by former students, which have dogged him for years and hampered his presidential campaign.

title: A Wave of Harassment After Trumps Victory
description: Hundreds of incidents of harassment and intimidation have been reported across the country since Election Day. Below are just a few:

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Myanmar Urged by U.N. Expert to Let Aid Flow to Rakhine State
description: GENEVA  Amid mounting reports of violent unrest and brutal reprisals by Myanmars army in a predominantly Muslim part of Rakhine State, a United Nations expert said on Friday that the countrys government should let aid agencies into the area and investigate allegations of abuse instead of brushing them aside with blanket denials.

title: With National Security Choices, Trump Builds Team to Bulldoze Status Quo
description: WASHINGTON  President-elect Donald J. Trumps trio of hard-line selections on Friday served notice that he intends not only to reverse eight years of liberal domestic policies but also to overturn decades of bipartisan consensus on the United States proper role in world affairs.

title: Thanksgiving Can Be Bland. Your Leftovers Dont Have to Be.
description: Whatever the particulars of your Thanksgiving meal, odds are the grocery list resembles a Simon and Garfunkel song: parsley, sage, rosemary and thyme.

title: Off Broadway Equity Actors and Stage Managers Win Pay Increase
description: Off Broadway theaters, under pressure from an aggressive social media campaign by performers, have agreed to pay higher salaries to hundreds of actors and stage managers.

title: Trump, Sessions, Pompeo, Flynn: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: xgzdiiiiiicdiirrwjfffffffff (pronounced grief). Not a Typo.
description: About 15 minutes into Gillian Walshs latest work, in the dim light of a studio at New York Live Arts on Thursday, I had a minor epiphany. The text that the performers were reading sounded familiar. Had I read it on Facebook? Could that be right?

title: Should Trump Undo Investor Protections? Meet the Brokers of Madison County
description: NEW WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  No, not that Woodstock, the one of peace, love and extremely good vibes.

title: Canada Today: Gay Curlers, Fracking Studies and a Payroll Nightmare
description: Major computer systems often have fitful starts. Two years ago, the website built for enrollment in President Obamas health care program provided a particularly notorious example.

title: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Fights a Ruling on Its Constitutionality
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is fighting back against a federal courts ruling last month that the agencys structure is unconstitutional.

title: Nepal Releases 41 Tibetans Detained While on Pilgrimage
description: Forty-one Tibetans who were detained by the Nepalese police while they were on a bus bound for India have been released to a Nepalese human rights group, an advocate for Tibetan rights said Friday.

title: I Get Knocked Down by the Hill, but I Get Up Again
description: LEEDS, England  Im just back from a run. An hour with friends from my running club, along a forested ridge close to my home, with various loops, climbs and scrambles, at night, wearing headlamps. The lack of sun at this time of year seeks to keep us on lighted roads, but heres the first nighttime run of the autumn season; we kick through wet leaves, skip over slippery tree roots and jump from boulder to boulder as we cross the hills crest.

title: On a New Jersey Speedway, a Thanksgiving Tradition Takes Another Lap
description: WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J.  Diane Krause darted around Wall Stadium Speedway as if she were on her own time trial, doing everything from selling ice cream and plump racing tires to running the business office as she prepared for the best-known event at this 66-year-old racetrack.

title: David Mancuso, Whose New York Loft Was a Hub of 70s Night Life, Dies at 72
description: David Mancuso, a self-described musical host who revolutionized night life in New York with weekly dance parties he gave at his downtown loft, beginning in 1970, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Your Deathbed Playlist
description: Health care proxy? Check. Power of attorney? Signed. My playlist for dying? Its done.

title: Fixation on Fake News Overshadows Waning Trust in Real Reporting
description: Something is deeply wrong when the popes voice, reputation and influence can be borrowed by a source that describes itself as a fantasy news site to claim that he has endorsed a presidential candidate, and then be amplified, unchallenged, through a million individual shares.

title: Trump Adviser Takes Stake in China Ride-Sharing Company
description: A hedge fund billionaire who was an economic adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump during the campaign has taken a position in a fast-growing Chinese ride-sharing company that recently signed a deal to acquire Uber Technologies operations in China.

title: New York Police Inspector Is Charged With Sexually Abusing Female Officer
description: A deputy inspector with the New York Police Department was charged on Friday with sexually abusing a female officer he supervised as the commanding officer of a Bronx precinct, the authorities said.

title: Andy and Jamie Murray, Once Sibling Rivals, Now Have the Same Quest
description: LONDON  Judy Murray was making the rounds in the players lounge earlier this week at the ATP World Tour Finals.

title: North Carolina Republicans Battle to Save Governor, Trailing by Whisker
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Democrats and Republicans in this fiercely contested political battleground have regularly resorted to creative legal maneuvers and election-law changes in their efforts to wring every last vote from the states nearly seven million voters. But even by that standard, the disputed, hairbreadth race for governor is plowing litigious and acrimonious ground.

title: Details About a Bodys Disposal in New Jersey Emerge
description: The sun had risen after a night out in Manhattan stretched into the morning, and Joseph Comunale was recorded by a security camera riding up an elevator in the luxury apartment building that was home to one of his fellow revelers.

title: Mayor de Blasios Political Standing Improves After Trump Win, but Perils Remain
description: In Mayor Bill de Blasios view, the election of Donald J. Trump was an almost apocalyptic upset: worrisome for immigrants, demoralizing for advocates of the poor and disastrous for just about all of New York  but not necessarily so for Mr. de Blasio.

title: Muslim Americans Speak of Escalating Worries
description: Muslim Americans, already alarmed by the election of Donald J. Trump, said Friday that Mr. Trumps choices for crucial posts heightened their fears of discrimination, violence, deportation and even detention.

title: Ex-General and Critic of Islam to Help Guide Trump in White House
description: Anyone who has spent time with Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, President-elect Donald J. Trumps choice for national security adviser, knows he is nothing if not blunt, especially when it comes to his near-obsessive focus on radical Islamic terrorism.

title: Why Democrats Now Need the F.B.I. Director, James Comey
description: WASHINGTON  After incurring their wrath for his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clintons email use, some Democrats now see James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, as a potential ally in trying to block President-elect Donald J. Trumps promises to revive the practice of sending terrorism suspects to the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and interrogate them using banned techniques such as waterboarding.

title: Diplomats Confront New Threat to Paris Climate Pact: Donald Trump
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco  Diplomats from around the world converged here this week with the plan to put details on last years Paris climate accord and move the globe closer to controlling the industrial emissions that are heating the planet.

title: To Hire Diverse Leaders, M.L.B. Looks Inward
description: Major League Baseball continues to struggle in its efforts to diversify the front offices of its teams, an issue that Commissioner Rob Manfred has stressed at the last few owners meetings.

title: Adam Ondra Expected a Short, Hard Climb. Now Hell Be Happy Just to Finish.
description: Adam Ondra, a 23-year-old from the Czech Republic considered by some to be the worlds best climber, thought he might cruise up the Dawn Wall of El Capitan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Just imagine what would happen if the Chinese started eating avocado.

title: The Mets Middleman Whos Always on Call
description: Two days before the start of last years winter meetings, Major League Baseballs annual convention, the Mets announced that General Manager Sandy Alderson could not attend the event in Nashville because he was dealing with a treatable form of cancer.

title: Hardly a Piece of Cake
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Most people who solve The New York Times Crossword at all know that the hardest day of the week is the Saturday puzzle. Thursday crosswords usually have a trick, but the clues are not necessarily ramped up like those in a Saturday puzzle. Fridays are the other themeless day of the week, but there is a bit of grace built in to make it ultimately solvable.

title: Jeff Sessions as Attorney General: An Insult to Justice
description: In 1986, President Ronald Reagan nominated Jeff Sessions, then a United States attorney from Alabama, to be a federal judge. The Republican-controlled Senate rejected Mr. Sessions out of concern, based on devastating testimony by former colleagues, that he was a racist.

title: 2 Nephews of Venezuelas First Lady Convicted on Drug Charges in U.S. Court
description: Two nephews of Venezuelas first lady were convicted in Manhattan on Friday of conspiring to transport cocaine to the United States.

title: Donald Trumps New York: The City of the Bonfire of the Vanities Set
description: When he ventured out of Trump Tower for a meal with his family on Tuesday, President-elect Donald J. Trump went to the 21 Club, a former speakeasy on West 52nd Street where cast-iron lawn jockeys line the balcony above the front door. It is all of four blocks from Trump Tower.

title: In Lower Manhattan, a Move to Integrate Some Schools Is Delayed
description: While the New York City Education Department has been trying to persuade parents on the Upper West Side to accept a rezoning plan aimed, in part, at diversifying the neighborhoods schools, it has told a group of Lower Manhattan parents that they must hold off on their desegregation plan.

title: Sharon Jones, Powerful Voice of Soul With the Dap-Kings, Dies at 60
description: Sharon Jones, the soul singer and powerful voice of the band the Dap-Kings, died on Friday of pancreatic cancer that had been in remission but returned last year. She was 60.

title: Michael Flynn: An Alarming Pick for National Security Adviser
description: Of all the disturbing scenes in the presidential campaign, the Republican Convention speech by retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn stood out. During a fiery address in which he lamented the decline of American exceptionalism and lambasted the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, General  Flynn joined the crowd in chants of lock her up! Smiling slyly, he shouted: Yeah, thats right, lock her up!

title: Oh, No! Donald Trumps Calling
description: Today, Donald Trump as diplomat. Were not talking about the big stuff, like his ominous national security appointments  I know youve had a hard week. Lets take it easy and just look at his phone calls with heads of state.

title: Appalachias Sacrifice
description: CULLOWHEE, N.C.  In a year dominated by political frenzy, the water crisis in Flint, Mich., was one of the few stories to grab the headlines away from the presidential race. Pallets of bottled water were donated. Celebrities ran fund-raisers. Congressmen grilled the mayor and the governor, demanding to know how they could let their citizens drink poisoned water. A handwritten warning posted above a drinking fountain became a national disgrace.

title: Why I Had to Eat a Bug on CNN
description: LAST weekend I ate a cricket on national television. Based on my statistical analysis of presidential polls, I made a bet that if Donald J. Trump won  more than 240 Electoral College votes, I would chow down. Like millions of voters in both parties, I was surprised by the outcome. As a consolation, Id like to learn what went wrong  and to figure out how pollsters might do better when they puzzle over our polarized electorate.

title: Ukraines Imported Corruption Busters
description: The whole saga of Mikheil Saakashvili, the former president of Georgia, showing up in Ukraine as the corruption-fighting governor of Odessa has been a curious one, as was his resignation last week with a loud flurry of attacks  on the resistance of the countrys leadership to reform. He also announced that he was forming a new Ukrainian political party. Setting aside Mr. Saakashvilis political ambitions, the episode once again cast light on the tenacity of Ukraines culture of corruption.

title: Cornel West Will Return to Teach at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Cornel West, the fiery African-American scholar who broke with Harvard University 14 years ago and whose searing critiques of President Obama earned him the enmity of many on the left, has been invited back to the university to teach.

title: Why Korematsu Is Not a Precedent
description: The Supreme Courts infamous 1944 Japanese internment decision, Korematsu v. United States, has never been overturned. But does that mean, as some of Donald J. Trumps associates have recently implied, that it is still good law, a precedent that could be cited in support of a national registry for Muslim immigrants or other morally repugnant classification schemes?

title: Hamilton Had Some Unscripted Lines for Pence. Trump Wasnt Happy.
description: Hamilton, the hit Broadway musical about colonial rebels shaping the future of an unformed country, took an even more political turn at the end of its performance on Friday night.

title: Corrections: November 19, 2016
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Race, and Kristen Wiig hosts S.N.L.
description: Race traces the footsteps of the Olympic runner Jesse Owens. Kristen Wiig hosts S.N.L. for the second time. And Sally Hawkins giggles her way through Happy-Go-Lucky, part of a tribute to the director Mike Leigh.

title: Hamilton Cast Sends Message to Pence
description: On Friday night, Mike Pence attended the Broadway musical in New York. After the performance, the actor Brandon Victor Dixon delivered a message to the vice president-elect.

title: Voting Rights in the Age of Trump
description: In June 2013, the Supreme Court ruled in Shelby County v. Holder that states with a long history of racial discrimination no longer needed to approve any proposed changes to their voting procedures with the federal government, as had long been required under the Voting Rights Act. That meant this years presidential election was the first in 50 years without the full protections of the act.

title: Never Trump Stalwarts Try to Focus on Policy, Not the Man
description: WASHINGTON  If they squint hard enough, they can see hope in the form of an ambitious piece of legislation like a big tax cut. Then there is the fact that Hillary Clinton will not be president. And Mike Pence, the faithfully conservative vice president-elect, is there to keep watch.

title: Showdown Looms as U.S. Questions Chinese Deal for German Chip Designer
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese company is setting up a rare and potentially tone-setting showdown with the American government over its deal to buy a high-tech firm that the United States says could impact national security.

title: Facebook Considering Ways to Combat Fake News, Mark Zuckerberg Says
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After more than a week of accusations that the spread of fake news on Facebook may have affected the outcome of the presidential election, Mark Zuckerberg published a detailed post Friday night describing ways the company was considering dealing with the problem.

title: This Election Changed My Mind About America
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Sculptures That Change With the Tides
description: Explore Doug Aitkens underwater sculptures, accessible only to scuba divers off the coast of Catalina Island in California.

title: Living in the Capitol Hill Historic District, Washington, D.C.
description: The neighborhood is where monumental, white-stone Washington intersects with a quirky village.

title: Capitol Hill Historic District, Washington, D.C.: Surprisingly Homey
description: For Meaghan Hannan Davant, Capitol Hill is not the throbbing, recently convulsed heart of political power in Washington, D.C., but an unpretentious small town. People dont wear makeup, said Ms. Davant, a 39-year-old lawyer, who has been living in the Capitol Hill Historic District since 2006. They wear yoga pants and drive Honda Odysseys. We do walk down the streets and see the newscasters and senators, but theyre in their sweatpants, just like us.

title: The Race for a Zika Vaccine
description: MADISON, Wis.  The Zika virus thrives in tropical climates. But it is also growing in this cold-weather city  up a flight of stairs, past a flier for lunchtime yoga and behind a locked door. That is where scientists working in a lab for Takeda, the Japanese drug company, inspect and test vials of the virus.

title: Move Over, Neptune. Doug Aitken Has Another Big Idea.
description: OFF THE COAST OF CATALINA ISLAND  At first, the fish avoided the intruder. A couple of beefy sheepshead hid in the kelp near the shore. The electric orange Garibaldi swam in the other direction. A small school of blacksmith darted away.

title: Ivory Coast Style
description: Hair, a study by the photographer milie Rgnier, chronicles the various styles, some of them influenced by Beyonc and Rihanna, in the city of Abidjan, Ivory Coast. Ms. Rgnier made her portraits in the manner of the photographs she saw in the look books available to customers of the local hair salons.

title: When Tech Is a Problem Child
description: In the Broadway classic The Music Man, set in 1912, the con artist Harold Hill shows up in River City, Iowa, and attempts to persuade the otherwise contented townspeople that their youth are slipping into degradation. He singles out a billiard parlor, the devils playground, as the root.

title: In Vermonts Bid to Lure Pro Skiers, a Warm Welcome Is Unwanted
description: KILLINGTON, Vt.  For the last 25 years, the World Cup of skiing has spurned the Eastern United States, favoring instead the West and its more bountiful snow.

title: Americas Great Divide  About How to Archive Its Fashion
description: DEARBORN, MICH.  Three days into November, before the election cleaved the nation into Swiss cheese, red and blue were commingling in perfect harmony  on a silk gauze gown from 1856.

title: Tom Ford, Ben Mankiewicz and a Fashion-Film Vortex
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Tom Ford was on the job as Ben Mankiewicz took a last look at himself before the photographer got to work. Hair looks good; stubble looks good, Mr. Ford said. But you need to button your jacket on camera. Every time I watch you on TCM, your jacket is undone.

title: Ivory Coast Style
description: The photographer milie Rgnier chronicles popular looks, influenced by Beyonc and Rihanna, in the hair salons of Abidjan, Ivory Coast.

title: How to Plan an Extended Vacation
description: Having two or three weeks off for your next vacation is undoubtedly a luxury, but, depending on how you plan, the trip could be time well spent or wasted, according to Sam McClure, the owner of Small World Travel in Austin, Tex., who specializes in creating customized extended itineraries.

title: Tens of Thousands of Protesters Call for Najib Razak, Malaysian Leader, to Resign
description: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia, on Saturday to call for the resignation of Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is accused of taking $1 billion from a government investment fund.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Italys Zone of Endless Shaking
description: NORCIA, Italy  Over centuries, residents of this Umbrian city and its environs have grown accustomed to the ragged tempo of earthquakes in the mountainous region. Resilience is a point of local pride. But the quake that struck on Oct. 30, the strongest to hit Italy in 36 years, was drastically different. As Mayor Nicola Alemanno of Norcia put it, some quakes are cataclysms that generate catastrophes.

title: Infrastructure Build or Privatization Scam?
description: Trumpists are touting the idea of a big infrastructure build, and some Democrats are making conciliatory noises about working with the new regime on that front. But remember who youre dealing with: if you invest anything with this guy, be it money or reputation, you are at great risk of being scammed. So, what do we know about the Trump infrastructure plan, such as it is?

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Fake News, Trolls and Other Spectacles
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Donald Trump and the U.N.: Signs of Clashing Views on Many Issues
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the genteel, carpeted halls of the United Nations headquarters, a 20-minute walk from Trump Tower, diplomats from the world over are holding their breath about the American president-elect.

title: Germany Cracks Down on Salafists to Shield Refugees
description: HILDESHEIM, Germany  For years, the authorities in Germany have warily monitored the swelling ranks of Salafists, followers of an ultraconservative branch of Islam who are known for aggressive proselytizing and their sympathies for the Islamic State.

title: Will Removing a Tub Affect Apartment Value?
description: Q. My husband and I live in a 1,000-square-foot Junior 4  in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. We have one bathroom and are considering replacing the shower-and-tub combination with just a shower, because we almost never take baths. Without a tub, the bathroom would feel more open, but would removing it affect our resale value? And is this something we should worry about even if we do not plan to sell for many years?

title: Enthusiasm for Trump in Poland Is Tempered by Distrust of Putin
description: WARSAW  Europes right-wing populists have scrambled to outdo one another in celebrating Donald J. Trump as an American president who shares many of their nationalistic, anti-immigrant attitudes. Less thrilled are the hard-liners in Poland. And the problem is Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Turkey Cheered by Words of Michael Flynn, Trumps Security Adviser
description: ISTANBUL  Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, the designated national security adviser for the incoming Trump administration, once wrote on Twitter that it was rational to fear Muslims, but that does not seem likely to cause him any grief with Turkeys government, even though it is led by a religiously conservative Muslim, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: A Bleak Outlook for Trumps Promises to Coal Miners
description: Donald J. Trump made coal a centerpiece of his campaign, holding rousing rallies with miners in hard hats, who he said had been neglected under eight years of the Obama administration. The strategy paid off, helping him score crucial wins in Pennsylvania and Ohio.

title: Italys Banks Are in a Slow-Motion Crisis. And Europe May Pay.
description: MILAN  Victor Massiah has grown weary of talk that the Italian banking system is so threadbare and stuffed with terrible loans that it threatens Europe with another financial crisis.

title: 4 Years After Hurricane Sandy, 2 Households Still Wait to Go Home
description: Although Hurricane Sandy hit New York on Oct. 29, 2012, the nightmare that came with it has lasted four years for the Rodriguez family. They, like tens of thousands of others in New York and New Jersey, lost their homes in the disaster.

title: MSNBC Host Left TV Battles Behind to Fight Poverty Instead
description: When Dylan Ratigan was last on daily television, he was often in a bit of a rage. After two highly publicized rants about unseemly ties between corporations and politicians on MSNBC, he left his show in 2012.

title: Chinas Influence Grows in Ashes of Trans-Pacific Trade Pact
description: LIMA, Peru  A toxic political war over money, jobs and globalization killed the vast and complex trade deal that was supposed to be a signature legacy of President Obama. But the deal, between the United States and 11 Asian and Pacific nations, was never just about trade.

title: How the Iranian-Saudi Proxy Struggle Tore Apart the Middle East
description: Behind much of the Middle Easts chaos  the wars in Syria and Yemen, the political upheaval in Iraq and Lebanon and Bahrain  there is another conflict.

title: Quit Social Media. Your Career May Depend on It.
description: Im a millennial computer scientist who also writes books and runs a blog. Demographically speaking I should be a heavy social media user, but that is not the case. Ive never had a social media account.

title: High in Tower, Trump Reads, Tweets and Plans
description: Donald J. Trump sits high in Trump Tower in New York, spending hours on the phone with friends, television personalities and donors to ask if they know people to recommend for his cabinet.

title: An Urban Gardener Who Grew Up to Be a Planeteer
description: Ain Chik, 34, is an operations manager at the Captain Planet Foundation in Atlanta.

title: Its Not Just the White House. Change Is in the Air on Wall St., Too
description: The markets are always fickle, but since the presidential election, the tastes of traders in stocks, bonds and commodities have conspicuously changed.

title: Trump Meets With Romney as He Starts to Look Outside His Inner Circle
description: BEDMINSTER, N.J.  President-elect Donald J. Trump on Saturday moved to mend fences with political rivals after a divisive campaign, meeting with Mitt Romney, who had scathingly criticized him during the race as a phony and a fraud, to discuss naming him as secretary of state.

title: A $28,000 Mystery: Will the Real Toner Supplier Please Stand Up?
description: The Haggler loves a great consumer mystery. Like, why are hotel thermostats so varied and confounding? Do we really need smart refrigerators? And heres one that recently flitted across the Hagglers mind: When Taco Bell conceived its Cheesy Core Burrito  basically, a cheese burrito stuffed inside a beef burrito  did it ever consider cramming the whole concoction into yet another, even bigger burrito and calling it the Triple Dare?

title: M.L.B.s Prosperity Comes With Labor Peace, and Only Quiet Complaints
description: The most significant change in baseball in the last two decades is labor peace between the owners and the players. That is saying something, given how much has changed in the way the game is run and played. But without cooperation, changes never happen. Without labor peace, there is no sport.

title: The In-Law in the Trump Inner Circle: Jared Kushners Steadying Hand
description: It was the low point for a campaign that had been in steady decline for weeks.

title: Carrier Workers for Trump
description: Can Trump Save Their Jobs? by Nelson D. Schwartz (Nov. 13), looked at workers at a Carrier plant in Indianapolis that will soon close, with production moving to Mexico. Some of the workers interviewed spoke of their support for Donald J. Trump.

title: Julie Zuckerman and Ryan Gessin: On Nantucket Sand, Love Finds Its Footing
description: Julie Appleton Zuckerman, the daughter of Betsy Appleton and Dr. Eric J. Zuckerman of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married Nov. 19 to Ryan Paul Gessin, the son of Faye Gessin and Corey Gessin of Orangeburg, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Pernick officiated at the Yale Club of New York.

title: Mens Tennis Wants to Crack Down on Tanking. But What, Exactly, Is Tanking?
description: LONDON  During a tennis season pockmarked by match-fixing reports, high-profile doping busts, sexist comments by tournament directors and superstars sidelined by injuries, tanking would seem to be low on the list of priorities.

title: Grandson of Lawmaker Danny Davis Is Fatally Shot in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  A teenage grandson of Representative Danny K. Davis was killed on Friday night after two people forced their way inside a home and argued with the teenager before one of them pulled a gun and fired, the police said. The fight may have been over a pair of shoes.

title: Share Your Story about Being a College Student with Autism
description: Have you or a family member received a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder and attended college? If so, we would like to learn more about your experiences.

title: Along the Autism Spectrum, a Path Through Campus Life
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  Crosby J. Gardner has never had a girlfriend. Now 20 and living for the first time in a dorm here at Western Kentucky University, he has designed a fast-track experiment to find her.

title: Variety: Building Blocks
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  My sincere apologies to Will Shortz; I am recovering from surgery this week and accidentally skipped writing up the Variety post.

title: Off to Flying Start, Patrik Laine Lifts Spirits in Winnipeg
description: PHILADELPHIA  Patrik Laine encountered a grand total of one boo when he stepped onto the ice Thursday for the first shift of his first game against the Philadelphia Flyers. The citys rugged fans know hockey well enough to spot a powerful adversary worthy of their badgering. But Laine, the Winnipeg Jets 18-year-old right wing, got a reprieve.

title: Jimmie Johnson Goes for History as a Nascar Season Full of Uncertainty Concludes
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  The Nascar season heads into its finale this weekend, with history on the line for Jimmie Johnson, who can tie Richard Petty and Dale Earnhardt Sr. with his seventh series championship.

title: At Iowa High School, Election Results Kindle Tensions and Protests
description: IOWA CITY  The air felt leaden in the hallways at West High School on the morning after Election Day. The usual clatter from the buildings 2,000 students was muffled. At lunchtime, Lujayn Hamad was in the cafeteria when she said a boy she barely knew roughly bumped into her and swore at her.

title: Trump Embarrasses Himself and Our Country
description: Early signs of what the Trump administration may look like: A man associated with white supremacy and misogyny will be White House chief strategist; a man rejected for a judgeship because of alleged racism will be attorney general; and an Islamophobe who has taken money from Moscow will be national security adviser.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: The Crisis for Liberalism
description: THE 2016 campaign was a crisis for conservatism; its aftermath is a crisis for liberalism. The right, delivered unexpectedly to power, is taking a breather from introspection as it waits to see what Trumpism means in practice. The left, delivered unexpectedly to impotence, has no choice but to start arguing about how it lost its way.

title: Dancing in a Hurricane
description: BRITAINS vote to withdraw from the European Union followed by Donald Trumps election in America constitute a single giant political event  one that makes 2016 a vintage year in history that will long be studied. Big political events have big causes. For the last three years Ive been working on a book about whats been happening beneath the surface  in the plumbing and wiring of the world  thats roiling politics in so many places. My answer begins with a question: What the hell happened in and around 2007?

title: Undocumented in Trumps America
description: On election night, while I was making my way through a crowd gathered outside the Fox News headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, a white man wearing a Mets cap patted my back and said through the noise: Get ready to be deported. Rattled, I made it inside the green room and waited to go on the air.

title: Facebook and the Digital Virus Called Fake News
description: This year, the adage that falsehood flies and the truth comes limping after it doesnt begin to describe the problem. That idea assumes that the truth eventually catches up. Theres not much evidence of this happening for the millions of people taken in by the fake news stories  like Pope Francis endorsing Donald Trump or Mr. Trump pulling ahead of Hillary Clinton in the popular vote  that have spread on social media sites.

title: Is Rock n Roll Dead, or Just Old?
description: This has been a bad year for music legends. First David Bowie, Glenn Frey and Maurice White. Then Prince and George Martin.

title: Obama May Jump Into Fray as Democrats Counter Trump
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is rethinking his plans to withdraw from the political arena after he leaves office next year, hinting to friends and supporters that he wants to add his voice to the shellshocked Democratic activists and elected officials who are now angrily vowing to oppose Donald J. Trumps presidency.

title: Sharon Jones, Powerhouse Soul Singer, Dies at 60
description: Sharon Jones, a powerhouse soul singer with a gritty voice, fast feet and indomitable energy, died Friday of pancreatic cancer. She was 60.

title: Reddit and the God Emperor of the Internet
description: On the morning of Nov. 9, a moderator who goes by the handle OhSnapYouGotServed posted on a Reddit topic page called The_Donald: How does it feel, centipedes? The God Emperor said that we would get tired of winning. Are you tired of winning yet? Feel vindicated, centipedes. Its over and there is nothing they can do about it. We are the future.

title: Keeping the Drillers From Sacred Grounds
description: A ceremony all too familiar to American Indian tribes  the signing of still another agreement with federal officials  took place Wednesday in the Blackfeet country of Montana. But this time, instead of winding up on the losing end, the tribe enjoyed a welcome reversal of fortune in its long struggle to protect its sacred grounds. With Blackfeet leaders in ceremonial headdress, Interior Secretary Sally Jewell canceled 15 energy exploration leases in the Badger-Two Medicine Area along the majestic Rocky Mountain Front, halting the feared desecration of lands at the heart of the tribes creation story.

title: Westworld and the Moral Dilemma of Cyborgs
description: The mathematician Norbert Wiener founded the science of cybernetics in 1948 with a warning that has become a cornerstone of futurist writing. The computer age was still in its infancy when he cautioned that intelligent machines could wreak havoc on civilization  and perhaps even snuff it out  if we failed to handle them with humility and care.

title: How to Stay Sane While Black
description: I wish I could point to the moment when I first understood I was a thing to be hated. The first Im just not attracted to black girls. The first Do you work here?

title: The Wreckage of Obamas Legacy
description: Three days after the election, I gathered with a group of historians at Princeton for a conference about Barack Obamas presidency. The mood among the scholars, who had just written papers about the underappreciated accomplishments of the Obama administration, was bleak. We were discussing how quickly his programs would be dismantled, now that Republicans controlled the White House and Congress. Donald J. Trumps stunning election appeared to many to be a direct repudiation of the essential meaning of 2008, when the country elected its first African-American president.

title: In a Trump Era, Schumer Declares, Democrats Are the Barrier
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Chuck Schumer of New York wasnt planning on being leader of the Senate minority  and by extension the Democratic opposition  as the Trump era dawns in the nations capital.

title: Climate Change in Trumps Age of Ignorance
description: Stanford, Calif.  THE good news got pretty much drowned out this month: Yes, 2016 is on track to become the hottest year on record, but thankfully also the third year in a row to see relatively flat growth in global greenhouse gas emissions. With global economic growth on the order of 3 percent a year, we may well have turned a corner toward a sustainable climate economy.

title: Donald Trumps Art of the New Deal?
description: The demolition job is finished, and now a new Republican Party is arising from the rubble, its ultimate shape unclear. President-elect Donald J. Trump, the most conspicuous builder on the scene, is the undisputed leader of his party. But he also remains an outsider, as Republicans who opposed him said all the way to election night. The mounting tensions of the transition have done little to change this.

title: Victorias Secrets: What the Royal Archives Didnt Want You to Know About Englands Queen
description: SYDNEY, Australia  To work in the Royal Archives at Windsor Castle in England is one of the most delicious prizes for a researcher. Climbing the steps to the Round Tower, where you can read centuries-old correspondence between monarchs and their ministers, untie ribbons binding intimate family records and feel the parchment crackling in your fingers, is viscerally thrilling.

title: Cambridge Analytica and the Secret Agenda of a Facebook Quiz
description: Do you panic easily? Do you often feel blue? Do you have a sharp tongue? Do you get chores done right away? Do you believe in the importance of art?

title: Tim Kaine Readily Moves Out of Spotlight: This Is More Me
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Tim Kaines second-floor office is much as he left it, with a minifridge full of Virginia-made hummus and an iPod playlist heavy on bluegrass and classic rock. The trademark harmonicas have been holstered, at least for now, his audience shrinking from a spellbound national electorate to a spirited weekday gathering of the Virginia Chamber of Commerce.

title: One Thing Voters Agree On: Better Campaign Coverage Was Needed
description: THERE is a group of 10 friends in Charlotte, N.C., all women, all in their 50s, all white. Theyre college educated with successful careers, and they have a message for The New York Times: Come visit us.

title: Immigrants Who Came to U.S. as Children Fear Deportation Under Trump
description: Brought to the United States from Venezuela as a toddler, Carlos Roa was among the first young undocumented immigrants to be protected from deportation under a program President Obama set up in 2012 by executive action.

title: Why the Democrats Lost
description: Readers dissect what went wrong, and offer ideas about how the party can recover.

title: Obama Is Considering Removing N.S.A. Leader
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is considering removing Adm. Michael S. Rogers from his posts as leader of the National Security Agency and United States Cyber Command after top officials expressed frustration over the speed at which Admiral Rogers had moved to combat the Islamic State and over the agencys repeated loss of closely guarded secrets, administration and intelligence officials said Saturday.

title: Hamilton Casts Appeal to Pence Ignites Showdown With Trump
description: A surprising confrontation erupted on Saturday between President-elect Donald J. Trump and the cast and creators of the Broadway hit Hamilton, setting off furious debate over American principles like free speech, respect and the ability to challenge authority in the Trump era.

title: Lupita Tovar, Star of Spanish-Language Dracula, Dies at 106
description: Lupita Tovar, a Mexican-born actress who began her career in silent films and starred as an alluring heroine in the Spanish-language version of the 1931 horror classic Dracula, died on Nov. 12 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 106.

title: Crossed References
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  In a crossword puzzle, a crossed reference refers to a pair of clues that are tied together in some way, either because each of the entries is part of a common phrase, or because one entry describes the other.

title: In California, a Bastion of Red Waits for Trump to Nudge This Blue State
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Sandra Eudy has considered leaving for Texas. Tina Larson finds it hard to envision retiring here, with the states high taxes eating into her savings. And Greg Surgener would leave, if not for family obligations.

title: Man Is Fatally Shot and 2 Officers Are Hurt at Brooklyn Housing Complex
description: A man was fatally shot by the police at a public housing complex in Brooklyn on Saturday after he hit two officers with a police baton he had grabbed from one of them, the police said.

title: Obama Tries to Reassure Latin America About a Future With Donald Trump
description: LIMA, Peru  President Obama said here on Saturday that, while President-elect Donald J. Trump was unlikely to reverse the warming of ties with Cuba, he would almost certainly re-examine trade deals in Latin America.

title: Thousands of Mourners Celebrate Gwen Ifills Tenacity and Grace
description: WASHINGTON  When former Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. learned he would be sitting down for an interview with Gwen Ifill, he prematurely breathed a sigh of relief, thinking about the down-to-earth woman he had befriended through house parties and family barbecues.

title: Donald Trump Meeting Suggests He Is Keeping Up His Business Ties
description: WASHINGTON  President-elect Donald J. Trump met in the last week in his office at Trump Tower with three Indian business partners who are building a Trump-branded luxury apartment complex south of Mumbai, raising new questions about how he will separate his business dealings from the work of the government once he is in the White House.

title: White Nationalists Celebrate an Awakening After Donald Trumps Victory
description: WASHINGTON  For years, they have lurked in the webs dark corners, masking themselves with cartoon images and writing screeds about the demise of white culture under ominous pseudonyms. But on Saturday, in the wake of Donald J. Trumps surprising election victory, hundreds of his extremist supporters converged on the capital to herald a moment of political ascendance that many had thought to be far away.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its a different environment now. I feel very upset and afraid for my friends. People are using the election as an excuse to discriminate against each other openly.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: American Muslims follow the U.S. Constitution. We call upon this incoming administration to also follow it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I think its still possible to make energetic, thrashy music without necessarily walking around being these sulky, angry, sullen, dark people with black cartoon thunderstorms over their heads.

title: Corrections: November 20, 2016
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Lara Gibbons, Robert Herr
description: Lara Ann Gibbons, a daughter of Dr. Alice Gibbons and Todd Gibbons of Short Hills, N.J., was married Nov. 19 to Robert Joseph Herr, a son of Mary Lou Herr and Jack Herr of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Timothy Navin performed the ceremony at San Marco Catholic Church on Marco Island, Fla.

title: Emily Driesman, Daniel Keating
description: Dr. Emily Claire Driesman and Daniel Lawrence Keating were married Nov. 19 at Guastavinos, an event space in New York. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin officiated.

title: Suzanne Hershman, Ross Secler
description: Suzanne Marie Hershman, the daughter of Carol Connors Hershman and Sheldon J. Hershman of Tampa, Fla., was married Nov. 19 to Ross Daniel Secler, the son of Gloria Block Secler and Harold Secler of Buffalo Grove, Ill. Rabbi Daniel Bar-Nahum officiated at the Newberry Library in Chicago, with Cantor Roger Weisberg participating.

title: Kurt Grasinger, Donald Lutt
description: Kurt Wilhelm Grasinger and Donald Joseph Lutt are to be married Nov. 20 at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York. Madeline M. Pantaleo, a friend of the couple who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, is to officiate.

title: Elizabeth Fife, Jeremy Levine
description: Elizabeth Rachel Fife, the daughter of Lori R. Fife and Mark S. Fife of New York, was married Nov. 19 to Jeremy Ian Levine, a son of Terise Aglietti Levine and Martin S. Levine of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Rabbi Elliot J. Cosgrove officiated in the Great Hall on Ellis Island, with Rabbi Ethan H. Witkovsky participating.

title: Agatha Rudz, Matthew Miorelli
description: Agatha Joanna Rudz, a daughter of Ewa B. Rudz and Dariusz W. Rudz of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married there Nov. 19 to Matthew Miorelli, a son of Theresa Miorelli and Michael M. Miorelli of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Noel Clarke, a minister affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the Tarrytown House Estate, an event space.

title: Eleanna Varangis, Michael Burns
description: Eleanna Martha Lyman Varangis, the daughter of Barbara L. Lyman-Varangis and Panayotis N. Varangis of Bethesda, Md., was married Nov. 19 to Michael Ryan Burns, the son of Debra Merlin King and Martin R. Burns, both of Nashville. The Rev. Heidi Gessner, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Cloth Mill at Eno River, an event space in Hillsborough, N.C.

title: Dori Katz, Michael Price
description: Dori Beth Katz and Michael William Price were married Nov. 19 at the Ritz-Carlton Naples in Naples, Fla. Rabbi Adam Miller officiated.

title: Hillary Sieber, Adam Russman
description: Hillary Beth Sieber, a daughter of Jodi L. Sieber and Joseph S. Sieber of Weston, Mass., was married Nov. 19 to Adam Seth Russman, the son of Elyse D. Levin-Russman and Marc E. Russman of Canton, Mass. Rabbi Jeffrey A. Summit officiated at the Pine Brook Country Club in Weston.

title: Lauren Seigel, Mark Bernstein
description: Lauren Jennifer Seigel and Mark Adam Bernstein were married Nov. 19 at the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York. Elizabeth D. Pessala, a village justice of Westbury, N.Y., and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Casey McEnroe, Nolan Harte
description: Casey Elizabeth McEnroe, a daughter of Maria S. McEnroe and Robert J. McEnroe of Fairfax, Va., was married Nov. 19 to Nolan Thomas Harte, a son of Eileen McCormack Harte and Thomas M. Harte of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Paul Rourke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington.

title: Christopher Renfro, Zachary Wallace
description: Christopher Lawrence Renfro and Dr. Zachary Scott Wallace were married Nov. 19 at the Boston Public Library by Dr. Jacob Soumerai, a friend of the couple who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Jules Hulburd, Mark Koechling
description: Jules Alexandra Hulburd, a daughter of Carrie Louis Hulburd and Jon R. Hulburd of Phoenix, was married Nov. 19 to Mark Phillip Koechling, a son of Dr. Glenn W. Koechling of Essex Fells, N.J., and the late Brenda Maye Koechling.

title: Lindsey Ridell, Brian Charles
description: Lindsey Rae Ridell and Brian Lawrence Charles were married Nov. 19 at the JW Marriott Essex House in New York. Cantor Richard Botton officiated.

title: Andre Ward Takes Control and Then Crown From Sergey Kovalev
description: LAS VEGAS  A few days before Andre Ward and Sergey Kovalev stepped into a boxing ring here to battle it out for light heavyweight supremacy, Kovalevs promoter said that this would be the super fight that everyone wanted between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao but never got.

title: Valerie Gong, Gregory Ambrosia
description: Valerie Ruoting Gong and Gregory Earl Ambrosia were married Nov. 19 at Immaculate Heart of Mary in Atlanta. The Rev. Ragan Shriver, a Roman Catholic priest and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony.

title: Michelle Tremont, Marshall Boyd
description: Michelle Ann Tremont, a daughter of Susan A. Tremont and Dr. Timothy J. Tremont of Canonsburg, Pa., was married Nov. 19 to Lt. Cmdr. Marshall Thomas Boyd, the son of M. Michele Boyd of Boston, Pa., and Thomas E. Boyd of McKeesport, Pa.

title: Home, for Manchester United, Is Where the Draw Is
description: Manchester Uniteds manager, Jos Mourinho, rose from his chair and was about to leave the postmatch news conference when he turned to his audience, threw his arms up and said, Finally, Ive lost to Arsenal.

title: Park Geun-hye Was Accomplice in Extortion, South Korean Prosecutors Say
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Park Geun-hye acted as a criminal accomplice for her longtime friend in extorting tens of millions of dollars from businesses, prosecutors said on Sunday, dealing another blow to the South Korean leader, who faced a nationwide call to step down.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: American Music Awards and The Affair
description: Get your Sunday-night groove on with the American Music Awards. Follow Bruno Mars back to where it all began. And the troubled tale of Noah Solloway and his women resumes in Season 3 of The Affair.

title: Just a Friendly Chat Between 2 Worried Late-Night Hosts
description: NEWARK  As the two late-night comedians sat across from each other onstage at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here on Saturday night, Stephen Colbert asked John Oliver why he had not yet been given a commitment for four more seasons.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: 134 Fairview Avenue, Stamford

title: Goat Yoga
description: Yoga classes in Oregon are involving unlikely participants.

title: What Trumps Climate Legacy Could Look Like
description: How the president-elect deals with climate change could make him the man who shrunk America or the man who helped save the planet.

title: Donald Trump, Obama, Thanksgiving: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Train Derailment in India Kills More Than 100
description: NEW DELHI  Fourteen coaches of an Indian train derailed early Sunday, killing at least 108 people in one of the worst rail accidents here in recent years, the police said.

title: Bring a Yoga Mat and an Open Mind. Goats Are Provided.
description: ALBANY, Ore.  Ordinary yoga can feel complicated enough sometimes, with the focus on breathing, and the search for an intention that many yoga instructors ask students to reach deep within themselves to find.

title: Killers on a Shoestring: Inside the Gangs of El Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR  On a sultry evening in late July, the Salvadoran authorities executed their very first assault on what they called the financial cupola of Mara Salvatrucha, or MS-13, the largest of the ruthless gangs that have made El Salvador the murder capital of the world.

title: Alec Baldwin Returns to S.N.L. as President-Elect Trump
description: Alec Baldwins return to Saturday Night Live this weekend prompted another fiery response from President-elect Donald J. Trump on Twitter.

title: Angela Merkel to Seek 4th Term as Germanys Leader
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, under siege domestically but widely seen as a pillar of Western liberalism, announced on Sunday that she will seek a fourth term next year.

title: The Affair: Heres Where We Left Off
description: This preview includes spoilers for the first two seasons of The Affair.

title: Counterfeiting Trade Settles Into a New York Standby: Self-Storage Units
description: Time was, if you wanted a knockoff purse, you went to Canal Street in Chinatown and looked for a store with a back room. The police raided these stores and took the bags, but more always arrived. Finally, the handbag companies began to sue the landlords of the buildings, who in turn drove out the purse vendors.

title: Trump Turns Staid Process Into Spectacle as Aspirants Parade to His Door
description: BEDMINSTER, N.J.  President-elect Donald J. Trump has turned the vital, but normally inscrutable, process of forming a government into a Trump-branded, made-for-television spectacle, parading his finalists for top administration positions this weekend before reporters and the world.

title: Forced to Leave Odessa as a Girl, and Yearning for the Life She Knew Then
description: Lyubov Bilik fled the only home she knew in 1941. With her mother and two older sisters, she boarded a ship from Odessa, Ukraine, and eventually wound up near the northern foothills of the Caucasus Mountains, fleeing the slaughter of Jews by the Nazis and the Romanians. She was 12 at the time. Her father, who had been conscripted into the Soviet Army, was forced to stay behind.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: How Fake News Goes Viral: A Case Study
description: Eric Tucker, a 35-year-old co-founder of a marketing company in Austin, Tex., had just about 40 Twitter followers. But his recent tweet about paid protesters being bused to demonstrations against President-elect Donald J. Trump fueled a nationwide conspiracy theory  one that Mr. Trump joined in promoting.

title: N.F.L.: Theres Dallass Dak Prescott and Then All the Other Rookie QBs
description: Not all rookie quarterbacks are the same. Heres what else we learned in Week 11 in the N.F.L.:

title: As American as Apple Pie? The Rural Votes Disproportionate Slice of Power
description: In 1920, for the first time, the Census Bureau counted more people living in urbanized America than in the countryside. This hasnt been a rural nation ever since.

title: Netanyahu Faces Conflict-of-Interest Scrutiny in Submarine Deal
description: JERUSALEM  Dogged for decades by scandals ranging from the funding of family trips  to enormous ice cream bills, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is again under scrutiny, this time over a billion-dollar deal with Germany for the acquisition of three new submarines.

title: Hamilton Duel: Addressing the President-Elect on His Own Blunt Terms
description: The theater must always be a safe and special place.

title: Villagers Execution in China Ignites Uproar Over Inequality of Justice
description: BEIJING  Zhou Yunfei, a technology executive who owns a villa in eastern China, did not have much in common with an impoverished farmer more than 500 miles away who was convicted of murdering a village chief with a nail gun.

title: Indians Rush Frantically to Launder Their Black Money
description: MUMBAI, India  Indians ingenuity is being mightily tested as they rush to save their black money, stashes of hundreds of thousands, even millions, of rupees they have accumulated without paying taxes.

title: Aleppo, Donald Trump, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Houston Conwill, Whose Sculptures Celebrated Black Culture, Dies at 69
description: Houston Conwill, a sculptor best known for collaborative site-specific works celebrating African-American culture and spiritualism, died on Nov. 14 in the Bronx. He was 69.

title: Kanye West Calls Out Beyonc and Praises Trump in Onstage Tirade
description: Kanye West likened himself to Donald J. Trump at a concert on Saturday in California before tumbling into a 17-minute, free-associative speech addressing radio programmers, MTV, his friends and collaborators Jay Z and Beyonc, Hillary Clinton, Mark Zuckerberg and more.

title: Fantastic Beasts Is a Hit for Warner Bros.
description: LOS ANGELES  Warner Bros. and J. K. Rowling pulled off an exceptionally difficult magic trick over the weekend. Not only did they bring the Harry Potter film franchise back to life, they also did it without Harry Potter.

title: Andy Murray Beats Error-Prone Novak Djokovic to Retain No. 1 Ranking
description: LONDON  As Andy Murray closed in this fall on Novak Djokovics run of more than two years at No. 1 and then overtook him this month, one thing was missing: a punctuating win over Djokovic, his toughest and longest rival.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 21
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Donald Trump and the Bieber Doctrine
description: Sofia, Bulgaria  It seems no matter what happens with American politics, the 19th-century French thinker Alexis de Tocqueville has something to say about it. In his classic Democracy in America, he suggested that democratic politics was in need of drama; as an election nears, intrigues become more active, agitation more lively and more widespread. The entire nation falls into a feverish state. But, once the election has passed, everything becomes calm, and the river, one moment overflowed, returns peacefully to its bed.

title: Landon Collinss Development Keeps the Giants on the Rise
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A year ago, Landon Collins would stand at the back of the Giants secondary looking confused and fretful. A rookie safety, he was the Giants last line of defense and the last person the team could rely on. His head was swimming, even drowning, in the details of a playbook full of mystifying schemes and signals.

title: A Look at Apples Sprawling New Campus in Texas
description: The tech giants rapid growth in Austin provides a window into the vast constellation of jobs at the company and their economic impact.

title: How Apple Empowers, and Employs, the American Working Class
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  During the presidential campaign, President-elect Donald J. Trump complained that America had lost too many manufacturing jobs and promised to force big companies like Apple to bring that work home. Im going to get Apple to start making their computers and their iPhones on our land, not in China, he said.

title: Review: Brahms at the Boston Smphony, With Hlne Grimaud
description: BOSTON  The British critic Richard Osborne once wrote that, when it comes to Brahmss symphonies, there are First and Third conductors, and Second and Fourth conductors. The scheme is loose and doesnt apply to everyone, particularly not to visionaries or stoics, but it captures the difficulties in maintaining consistency across the cycle.
